editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SEASONS. IN FOUR BOOKS. WITH BRITANNIA. BY JAMES THOMSON.

To which are added the following Pieces,
I. Ode on St. Cecilia's Day, by Mr. POPE.
II Alexander's Feat, or the Power of Muick, by Mr. DRYDEN.
III. Ode on Solitude, by Mr POPE.
IV. The dying Chritian to his Soul, an Ode, by the ame.
V. The Univeral Prayer, by the ame.
VI. Elegy, to the Memory of an unfortunate Lady, by the ame.
VII. Veni Creator Spirittus, tranlated in Paraphrae, by Mr. DRYDEN.
To which is prefixed, The LIFE and LITERARY CHARACTER of Mr. THOMSON.
Illutrated with a new Set of DESIGNS
PHILADELPHIA: Pinted for RICE and Co. MARKET-STREET. MDCCLXXXVIII.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p: THE Methods now purued in teaching the Englih Tongue, are uch as give all the Advantages, that formerly could only be acquired by an Acquaintance with the dead Languages; This has raied its Value, and brought into Eteem many of the Productions, and elegant Compoitions, that have appeared in the Englih Language, whoe Beauties and Value were hitherto, only perceptible to thoe who had laboured in the learned Languages, or had walked in the Fields of Science.

The preent Method of teaching the Englih Language, adopted in our firt Schools, where Gentlemen of the mot claical as well as liberal Education preide, not only leads the Scholar into a proper Knowledge of Grammar, but introduces him to the more polite Parts of Literature, whereby he is intructed in Syntax, Proody, and all the Beauties of Trope and Figure, &c. Thee, while they refine the Tate, enlarge the Conception, and o improve the Mind, as to fit it for the mot rational of all Amuements, that of tudying a good Author, entering thoroughly into his Meaning, and as it were imbibing his Spirit. In thee Puruits ome of the
mot admired of the Englih Writers, both in Proe and Vere, have been introduced into our Schools; whoe Beauties and Excellencies being firt laid before the Pupil by his Tutor, he in a little Time becomes capable of himelf to point them out. And as that Part of THOMSON'S WORKS, which include the SEASONS, is particularly adapted to the Purpoe, a very correct Edition is here offered, Printed from his lat Corrections; to which is added his Poem, entitled, BRITANNIA, which breathing the Spirit of true Patriotim, Liberty, and Love of Mankind, is peculiarly well calculated for Youth and tender minds; and, as our Author himelf exprees it,
—"to rear the tender Thought,
To teach the young Idea how to hoot,
To pour the freh Intruction o'er the Mind,
To breathe th' enlivening Spirit, and to fix
The generous Purpoe in the glowing Breat." SPRING, 1148.
But that this Piece may be till more ueful, and more fully to anwer the Deign, and lead the Youth into a Variety of the pleaing Paths of Poetry, a Collection of other Pieces are here inerted, to intruct him in the Beauties of an Ode, an Elegy, &c. without raiing the Purchae above the Rate of common School Books.

div.head: THE LIFE AND LITERARY CHARACTER OF JAMES THOMSON; Pointing out ome particular Beauties of the Author for the Ue of young Minds.
div.p:
JAMES THOMSON, an eminent Britih poet, was the on of a Divine in Scotland, and born at Ednam, in the hire of Roxburgh, the eleventh of September, 1700. He gave early marks of genius, which was dicoverable through the rudenes of his puerile eays; and, after the uual coure of chool education at J • dburgh, was ent to the univerity of Edinburgh. In the econd year of his admiion, his tudies were for ome time interrupted by the death of his father; but his mother oon after repaired with her family, which was very numerous, to Edinburgh, where h • lived in a decent frugal manner, till her favourite on had not only finihed his academical
coure, but was even d • tinguihed and patronized as a genius. About this time the tudy of poetry became pretty general in Scotland, the bet Englih authors being univerally read, and imitations of them attempted; but tate as yet had made but little progres, cr • ticim being there limited to rules and forms, which erved only to dicover the inaccuracies of a poet, while his fire and fancy ecaped their notice. Thomon, who believed he was entitled to judges of a more exalted genius, began to turn his views towards London which an accident oon after intirely determined him in.

The divinity chair at Edinburgh was then filled by Mr Hamilton, whoe lectures our author attended ab • ut a year, when in an exercie in the palm, in which the power and majety of God were celebrated, he gave o highly poetical and ublime a paraphrae and illutration, that it urprized the whole audience. Mr. Hamilton complimented him on this performance in a particular manner; but at the ame time told him, in his miles of approbation, that if he expected to be ueful in the minitry, he mut keep a tricter rein upon his imagination, and expres himelf in language more uitable to an audience, where the learned and unlearned are equally repectable. Thomon concluded from this, that his expectations from the tudy of theology might be precarious, even though the church had been his choice; o that, having ome encouragement from a lady of quality, a friend of his mother, then in London, he quickly prepared for his journey, which ended in no more than giving him an opportunity of entering on the tage of the unknown world, without a patron, and but paringly provided with cah.

However, his merit did not lie long concealed. Mr. Forbes, af • erw • rds lord prei • ent of the eion, received him very kindly, and introduced him to ome of his friends, part • cularly to Mr. Aickman, whoe premature death he has with great affection commemorated, • n a copy of veres written on that occaion. The favourable manner in which he was every where received, emboldened him to rik the publicat • on of his Winter, in March • 726, which wa • no ooner read than univ • rally admired; and from that time his acquaintance was courted by all men of tate Dr. Rundle, afterwards bihop of Lerry, received him into his intimate confidence and friendhip; promoted his character every where: introduced him to his great friend the lord chancellor Talbot; and ome years after, when the eldet on of that nobleman was to make his tour, recommended Mr Thomon as a proper companion for him. His affection and gratitude to Dr. Rundle are finely expreed, in his poem to the memory of lord Talbot. Our author held the etimation of the public o highly, that he finihed the plan which their wihes laid out for him; and the expectations which his Winter had raied, were fully anwered in the ucceive publication of the other eaons; Summer, in the year • 727; Spring, in the beginn • ng of 1728; and Autumn, in a quarto edition of his works, in 1730.

Beides thee, and his tragedy of Sophonib • , which was well received in the year 1729, Mr. Thomon had, in 1727, publihed his poem to the memory of Sir Iaac Newton, th • n lately deceaed. The ame year, the reentment of our merchants, for the interruption of their trade by the Spaniards in America running very high, Mr Thomon zea
• ouly took part in it, and wrote his poem Britannia,
to roue the nation to revenge. His poetical puruits were now interrupted by his attendance on the honourable Mr. Charles Talbot in his travels, with whom he viited mot of the courts and capital cities of Europe. How particular and judicious his obervations were, appears from his poem on Liberty, in five parts, thus in • itled. Ancient and Modern Italy compared; Gre • ce; Rome; Britain; the Propect. While he was writing the firt part of Liberty, he received a evere hock, by the death of his noble friend and fellow-traveller, and this was oon followed by another till more o, and of more general concern, the death of lord Talbot himelf; which Mr. Thomon o pathetically laments, in the poem dedicated to his memory. At the ame time he found himelf from an eay competency, reduced to a tate of precarious dependence, in which he paed the remainder of his life, excepting only the two lat years of it, during which he enjoyed the place of urveyor general of the Leeward ilands, procured for him by the generous friendhip of lord Lyttleton.

Immediately upon his return to England with Mr. Talbot, the chancellor had made him his ecretary of briefs, a place of li • tle attendance, uiting his retired indolent way of life, and equal to all his wants. This place • ell with his patron; yet his genius could not be depreed, or his temper hurt, by this revere of fortune. He reumed, in time, his uual chearfulnes, and never abated one article in his way of living; which, though imple, was elegant, and with a peculiar neatnes. The profits ariing from his works w • re not inconiderable; his • rag • dy of Agamemnon, acted in 1738, gave many nigh • s to the author.

But his chief dependence, during this long interval, was on the protection and bounty of his royal highnes Frederick Prince of Wales, who, upon the recommendation of lord Lyttleton, then his chief favourite, ettled on him an handome allowance, and always received him very graciouly. It happened, however, that the favour of his royal highnes was, in one intance, of ome prejudice to Mr. Thomon, in the refual of a licence for his tragedy of Edward and Eleanora, which he had prepared for the tage in the year 1739. This proceeded from the miundertand • ng which then ubited between the court of the prince of Wales, and that of the king his father. His next dramatic performance was the maque of Alfred, written jointly with Mr. Mallet, who was his good friend on many occaions, and by command of the prince of Wales, for the entertainment of his royal highnes's court at his Summer reidence In the year 1745, his Tancred and Sigimunda, taken from the novel in Gil Blas, was well received. He in the mean time, was finihing his Catle of Indolence, an allegorical poem, in two canto • . The tanza in which he wrote this piece is that of Spencer, borrowed from the Italian poets. This was the lat piece publihed by Mr. Thomon, his tragedy of C • ri • lanus being only. prepared for the theatre, when a fever eized him, and deprived the world of a very good man, as well as a very great poet. His death happened on the 27th of Augut, 1748. His executors were the lord Lyttleton and Mr. Mitchel; and, by their interet, the orphan play of Coriolanus was brought on the tage to the b • t advantage: from the pr • fits of which, and from the ale of his manucripts and other effects, all demands were duly atisfied, and a handome um
remitted to his iters. His remains were depoited in the church of Richmond, under a plain tone, without any incription.

Mr. Thomon himelf hints, omewhere in his works, that his figure was not the mot promiing, his make being rather robut than graceful; and his wort appearance was, when he was een walking alone, in a thoughtful mood: but when aluted by a friend and they entered into converation he would intantly brighten into a mot amiable apect, his features no longer the ame, and his eyes darting a peculiar and animated fire. He had improved his tate by the bet originals, both ancient and modern, b • t could not bear to write what was not trictly hi • own. What he borrowed from the ancients, he gives us in an avowed faithful paraphrae, or tranlation, as we ee in a few paages taken from Virgil, and in that beautiful picture from the elder Pliny, where the coure and gradual increae of the Nile are figured by the tages of man's life The Autumn was his favourite eaon for poetical compoition, and the deep ilence of the night the t • me he commonly choe for uch tudies: o that he would often be heard walking in his tudy till near morning, humming over, in his way, what he was to correct and write out the next day. The amuements of his leiure hours were civil and natural hitory, voyages, and the bet relations of travellers; and, had his ituation favoured it, he would certainly have excelled in gardening, agriculture, and every rural improvement and exercie. Although he performed on no intrument, he was paionately fond of muic, and would ometimes liten a full hour at his window to the nightingales in Richmond-gardens. Nor was
his tate les exquiite in the arts of painting, culpture, and architecture. In his travels, he had een all the mot celebrated monuments of antiquity, and the bet productions of modern art, and had tudied them o minutely, and with uch true judgment, that, in ome of his decriptions of his poem on Liberty, we have them o delineated as to place them in a tronger light, perhaps, than if we aw them with our eyes. As for the more ditinguihing qualities of his mind and heart, they are bet dicoverable in his writings, than they can be preented by the pen of any biographer. There his love of mankind, of his country and friends; his devotion to his God, founded on the mot elevated and jut conception of his operative power and providence, hines in every page. So unbounded was his tendernes of heart, that it took in even the brute creation: he was extremely tender towards his own pecies. He is not indeed known, through his whole life, to have given any peron one moment's pain by his writings, or otherwie. He took no part in the poetical quabbles of his time, and o was repected and left unditurbed by both parties. Thee amiable virtues, this divine temper of mind, did not fail of their due reward: the bet and greatet men of his time honoured him with their friendhip and protection: the applaue of the public attended all his productions; his friends loved him with an enthuiatic ardour, and incerely lamented his untimely death.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The ubject propoed. Incribed to the Countes of HARTFORD. The Seaon is decribed as it affects the various parts of Nature, acending from the lower to the higher; with digreions ariing from the ubject. Its influence on inanimate Matter, on Vegetables, on brute Animals, and lat on Man; concluding with a diuaive from the wild and irregular paion of Love, oppoed to that of a pure and happy kind.

lg.l: COME, gentle SPRING, ethereal Mildnes, come,
And from the boom of yon dropping cloud.
While muick wakes around, veil'd in a hower
Of hadowing roes, on our plains decend.
O HARTFORD, fitted, or to hine in courts
With unaffected grace, or walk the plain
With innocence and meditation join'd
In oft aemblage, liten to my ong,
Which thy own Seaon paints; when Nature all
Is blooming, and benevolent, like thee.
AND ee where urly WINTER paes off,
Far to the north, and calls his ruffian blats:
His blats obey, and quit the howling hill,
The hatter'd foret, and the ravag'd vale;
While ofter gales ucceed, at whoe kind touch,
Diolving nows in livid torrents lot,
The mountains lift their green heads to the ky.
AS yet the trembling year is unconfirm'd,
And WINTER oft at eve reumes the breeze,
Chills the pale morn, and bids his driving leets
Deform the day delightles: o that carce
The bittern knows his time, with bill ingulpht,
To hake the ounding marh; or from the hore
The plovers when to catter o'er the heath,
And ing their wild notes to the litening wate.
AT lat from Aries rolls the bounteous un,
And the bright Bull receives him. Then no more
Th' expanive atmophere is cramp'd with cold;
But, full of life and vivifying oul,
Lifts the light clouds ublime, and preads them thin,
Fleecy, and white, o'er all-urrounding heaven.
FORTH fly the tepid airs; and unconfin'd,
Unbinding earth, the moving oftnes trays,
Joyous, th' impatient hubandman perceives
Relenting Nature, and his luty teers
Drives from their talls, to where the well-us'd plough
Lies in the furrow, looen'd from the frot.
There, unrefuing, to the harnes'd yoke,
They lend their houlder, and begin their toil,
Chear'd by the imple o • g and oaring lark.
Meanwhile, incumbent o'er the hining hare,
The mater leans, removes th' obtructing clay,
Winds the whole work, and idelong lays the glebe.
WHITE, thro' the neighbouring fields the ower talks,
With meaur'd tep; and, liberal, throws the grain
Into the faithful boom of the ground:
The harrow follows harh, and huts the cene.
BE gracious, HEAVEN! for now laborious Man
Has done his part. Ye fotering breezes, blow!
Ye of • ening dews, ye te • der howers, decend!
And temper all, thou world-reviving un,
Into the perfect year! Not ye who live
In luxury and eae, in pomp and pride,
Think thee lot themes unworthy of your ear:
Such themes as thee the rural MARO ung
To wide-imperial ROME, in the full height
Of elegance and tate, by GREECE refin'd.
In antient times, the acred plough employ'd
The kings, and awful fathers of mankind:
And ome, with whom compar'd, your inect tribes
Are but the beings of a ummer's day,
Have held the cale of empire, rul'd the torm
Of mighty war; then, with unwearied victorious hand,
Didaining little delicacies, eiz'd
The plough, and greatly independent liv'd. corn'd
This line not in the lat Ed. All the vile tores corruption can betow.
YE generous BRITONS, venerate the plough!
And o'er your hills, and long withdrawing vales,
Let Autumn pread his treaures to the un,
Luxuriant, and unbounded: as the ea,
Far thro' his azure turbulent domain,
Your empire owns, and from a thouand hores
Wafts all the pomp of life into your ports;
So with uperior boon may your rich oil,
Exuberant, Nature's better bleings pour
O'er every land, the naked nations cloathe,
And be th' exhautles granary of a world!
NOR only thro' the lenient air this change,
Delicious, breathes; the penetrative un,
His force deep-darting to the dark retreat
Of vegetation, ets the teaming Power
At large, to wander o'er the vernant Earth,
In various hues; but chiefly thee, gay Green!
Thou miling Nature's univeral robe!
United light and hade! where the ight dwells
With growing trength, and ever-new delight.
FROM the moit meadow to the wither'd hill,
Led by the breeze, the vivid verdure runs,
And wells, and deepens, to the cherih'd eye.
The hawthorn whitens; and the juicy groves
Put forth their buds, unfolding by degrees,
Till the whole leafy foret tands diplay'd,
In full luxuriance, to the ighing gales;
Where the deer rutle thro' the twining brake,
And the birds ing conceal'd. At once, array'd
In all the colours of the fluhing year,
By Nature's wift and ecret-working hand,
The garden glows, and fills the liberal air
With lavih fragrance; while the promis'd fruit
Lies yet, a little embryo, unperceiv'd,
Within its crimon olds. Now from the town
Buried in moke, and leep, and noiome damps,
Oft let me wander o'er the dewy fields,
Where frehnes breathes, and dah the trembling drops
From the bent buh, as thro' the verdant maze
Or tate the mell of dairy; or acend
Some eminence, AUGUSTA, in thy plains,
And ee the country, far-diffus'd around,
One boundles bluh, one white-empurpled hower
Of mingled blooms; where the raptur'd eye
Hurries from joy to joy, and, hid beneath
The fair profuion, yellow Autumn pies.
I • , bruh'd from Ruian wilds, a cutting gale
Rie not, and catter from his humid wings
The clammy mildew; or, dry-blowing, breathe
Untimely frot; before whoe baleful blat,
The full-blown Spring thro' all her foliage hrinks,
Joyles, and dead, a wide-dejected wate.
For oft, engender'd by the hazy north,
Myriads on myriads, inect-armies waft
Keen in the poion'd breeze; and wateful eat,
Thro' buds and bark, into the blackened core,
Their eager way. A feeble race! yet oft
The acred ons of vengeance! on whoe coure
Corroive famine waits, and kills the year.
To check this plague the kilful farmer, chaff,
And blazing traw, before his orchard burns;
Till, all involv'd in moke, the latent foe
From every cranny uffocated falls:
Or catters o'er the blooms the pungent dut
Of pepper, fatal to the froty tribe:
Or, when th' envenom'd leaf begins to curl,
With prinkled water drowns them in their net:
Nor, while they pick them up with • uy bill,
The little trooping birds unwiely cares.
BE patient, wains; thee cruel-eeming winds
Blow not in vain. Far hence they keep, rep • es'd,
Thoe deepening clouds on clou • s, urcharg'd with rain,
That o'er the vat Atlantic hither • orne,
In endles train, would quench the ummer-blaze,
And, chearles, drown the crude unripen'd year.

THE north-eat pends his rage, h •
and now, hut up
Within his iron cave caves, th' effuive • outh
Warms the wide air, and o'er the void of heaven
Breathes the big clouds with vernal howers ditent.
At firt a duky wreath they eem to rie,
Scarce taining ether; but by wift fat degrees,
In heaps on heaps, the doubling vapour ails
Along the loaded ky, and mingling deep
Sits on the horion round a ettled gloom.
Not uch as wintry torms on mortals hed,
Oppreing life; but lovely, gentle, kind,
And full of every hope and every joy,
The wih of Nature. Gradual, inks the breeze,
Into a perfect calm; that not a breath
Is heard to quiver thro' the cloing woods,
Or rutling turn the many-twinkling leaves
Of apin tall. Th' uncurling floods, diffus'd
In glay breadth, eem'd thro' deluive lape
Forgetful of their coure. 'Tis ilence all,
And pleaing expectation. Herds and flocks
Drop the dry prig, and mute-imploring eye
The falling verdure. Huh'd in hort upence,
The plumy people treak their wings with oil,
To throw the lucid moiture trickling off;
And wait th' approaching ign to trike, at once,
Into the general choir. Even mountains, vales,
And forets eem, impatient, to demand
The promis'd weetnes. Man uperior walks
Amid the glad creation, muing praie,
And looking lively gratitude. At lat,
The clouds conign their treaures to the fields,
And, oftly haking on the dimpled pool
Preluive drops, let all their moiture flow,
In large effuion o'er the frehen'd world.
The tealing hower is carce to patter heard,
By uch as wander thro' the foret-walks,
Beneath th' umbrageous multitude of leaves.
• ut who can hold the hade, while Heaven decends
In univeral bounty, hedding herbs,
And fruits, and flowers, on Nature's ample lap?
Swift fancy fir'd anticipates their growth;
And, while the milky nutriment ditills,
Beholds the kindling country colour round.
THUS all day long the full-ditended clouds
Indulge their genial tores, and well-howered earth
Is deep enrich'd with vegetable life;
'Till, in the wetern ky, the downward un
Looks out, effulgent, from amid the fluh
Of broken clouds, gay-hifting to his beam.
The rapid radiance intantaneous trikes
Th' illumin'd mountain, thro' the foret treams,
Shakes on the floods, and in a yellow mit,
Far-moaking o'er th' interminable plain,
In twinkling myriads lights the dewy gems.
Moit, bright, and green, the landcape laughs around.
Full well the woods; their every muic wakes,
Mix'd in wild concert with the warbling brooks
Increas'd, the ditant bleatings of the hills,
And The hollow lows reponive from the vales,
Whence blending all the weeten'd zephyr prings.
Mean time refracted from yon eatern cloud,
Betriding earth, the grand ethereal bow
Shoots up immene; and every hue unfolds,
In fair proportion running from the red,
To where the violet fades into the ky.

While o'er his ample ides the rambling prays
Luxuriant hoot; or thro' the mazy wood
Dejected wanders, nor th' inticing bud
Crops, tho' it prees on his careles ene.
And oft, in jealous madning fancy wrapt,
He eeks the fight; and, idly-butting, feigns
His rival gor'd in every knotty trunk.
Him hould he meet, the bellowing war begins;
Their eyes flah fury; to the hollow'd earth,
Whence the and flies, they mutter bloody deeds,
And groaning deep th' impetuous battle mix:
While the fair heifer, balmy-breathing, near,
Stands kindling up their rage. The trembling teed,
With this hot impule eiz'd in every nerve,
Nor hears the rein, nor heeds the ounding thong;
Blows are not felt; but toing high his head,
And by the well-known joy to ditant plains
Attracted trong, all wild he burts away;
O'er rocks and woods, and craggy mountains flies;
And, neighing, on the aërial ummit takes
Th' exciting gale, then, teep decending, cleaves
The headlong torrents foaming down the hills,
Even where the madnes of the traiten'd tream
Turns in black eddies round; uch is the force
With which his frantick heart and inews well.
NOR undelighted, by the boundles Spring,
Are the broad monters of the foaming boiling deep:
From the deep ooze, and gelid cavern rous'd,
They flounce and tumble in unwieldy joy.
Dire were the train, and dionant, to ing
The cruel raptures of the avage kind:
How by this flame their native wrath ublim'd,
They roam, amid the fury of their heart,
The far-reounding wate in fiercer bands,
And growl their horrid loves. But this the theme
I ing, enraptur'd, to the BRITISH FAIR,
Forbids, and leads me to the mountain-brow,
Where its the hepherd on the gray turf,
Inhaling, healthful, the de • ending un.
Around him feeds his many-bleating flock,
Of various cadence; and his portive lambs,
This way and that convolv'd, in frikful glee,
Their frolicks play. And now the prightly race
Invites them forth; when wift, the ignal given,
They tart away, and weep the may mound
That runs around the hill; the rampart once
Of iron war, in ancient barbarous times,
When diu • ited BRITAIN ever bled,
Let in eternal broil: ere yet he grew
To this deep-laid indioluble tate,
Where Wealth and Commerce lift their golden heads;
And, o'er our labours, Liberty and Law,
Impartial, watch, the wonder of a world!
WHAT is this mighty Breath, ye ages curious, ay,
That in a powerful language, felt not heard, That, in a language rather felt than heard,
Intructs the fowls of heaven; and thro' their breat
Thee arts of love diffues? What, but GOD?
Inpiring GOD! who boundles Spirit all,
And unremitting Energy, pervades,
Adjuts, utains, and agitates the whole.
He ceaeles works alone, and yet alone
Seems not to work; with uch perfection fram'd
Is this complex tupendous cheme of things.
But, tho' conceal'd, to every purer eye
Th' informing Author in his works appears:
Chief, lovely Spring, in thee, and thy oft cenes,
The SMILING GOD is een while water, earth,
And air attet his bounty; which exalts
The brute-creation to this finer thought,
And annual melts their undeigning hearts
Profuely thus in tendernes and joy.
STILL let my ong a nobler note aume,
And ing th' infuive force of Spring on Man;
When heaven and earth, as if contending, vye
To raie his being, and erene his oul.
Can he forbear to join the general mile
Of Nature? Can fierce paions vex his breat,
While every gale is peace, and every grove
Is melody? Hence, from the bounteous walks
Of flowing Spring, ye ordid ons of earth,
Hard, and unfeeling of another's woe,
Or only lavih to yourelves; away.
But come, ye generous minds, in whoe wide thought,
Of all his works, CREATIVE BOUNTY burns
With warmet beam; and on your open front,
And liberal eye, its, from his dark retreat,
Inviting modet want. Nor, till invok'd,
Can retles goodnes wait; your active earch
Leaves no cold wintry corner unexplor'd;
Like ilent-working HEAVEN, urprizing oft
The lonely heart with unexpected good.
For you the roving pirit of the wind
Blows Spring abroad; for you the teaming cloud
Decend in gladome plenty o'er the world;
And the un heds his kindet rays for you,
Ye flower of human race!—In thee green days,
Reviving icknes lifts her languid head;
Life flows afreh; and young-ey'd health exalts
The whole creation round. Contentment walks
The unny glade, and feels an inward blis
Spring o'er his mind, beyond the power of kings
To purchae. Pure erenity apace
Induces thought, and contemplation till.
By wift degrees the love of Nature works,
And warms the boom; till at lat ublim'd
To rapture, and enthuiatic heat,
We feel the preent DEITY, and tate
The joy of GOD to ee a happy world.
THESE are the acred feelings of thy heart,
Thy heart inform'd by reaon's purer puret ray,
O LYTTELTON, the friend! thy paions thus
And meditations vary, as at large,
Courting the Mue, thro' Hagley-Park thou trayet; you tray,
Thy Britih Tempe! There along the dale,
With woods o'erhung, and hag'd with moy rocks,
Whence on each hand the guhing waters play,
And down the rough cacade white-dahing fall,
Or gleam in lengthen'd vita thro' the trees,
You ilent teal; or it beneath the hade
Of olemn oaks, that tuft the welling mounts
Thrown graceful round by Nature's careles hand,
And penive liten to the various voice
Of rural peace: the herds, the flocks, the birds,
The hollow-whipering breeze, the plaint of rills,
That, purling down amid the twited roots
Which creep around, their dewy murmurs hake
On the ooth'd ear. From thee abtracted oft,
You wander through the philoophic world;
Where in bright train continual wonders rie,
Or to the curious or the pious eye.
And oft, conducted by hitoric truth,
You tread the long extent of backward time:
Planning, with warm benevolence of mind,
And honet zeal unwarp'd by party-rage,
BRITANNIA's weal; how from the venal gulph
To raie her virtue, and her arts revive.
Or, turning thence thy view, thee graver thoughts
The Mues charm: while, with ure tate refin'd,
You draw th' inpiring breath of ancient ong;
Till nobly ries, emulous, thy own.
Perhaps thy lov'd LUCINDA hares thy walk,
With oul to thine attun'd. Then Nature all
Wears to the lover's eye a look of love;
And all the tumult of a guilty world,
Tot by ungenerous paions, inks away
The tender heart is animated peace;
And as it pours its copious treaures forth,
In vary'd convere, oftening every theme,
You, frequent-pauing, turn, and from her eyes,
Where meeken'd ene, and amiable grace,
And lively weetnes dwell, enraptur'd, drink
That nameles pirit of ethereal joy,
Unutterable Inimitable happines! which love,
Alone, betows, and on a favour'd few.
Meantime you gain the height, from whoe fair brow
The burting propect preads immene around;
And natch'd o'er hill and dale, and wood and lawn,
And verdant field, and darkening heath between,
And villages emboom'd oft in trees,
And piry towns by urging duky columns mark'd
Of houhold riing moak, your eye excurive roams:
Wide-tretching from the Hall, in whoe kind haunt
The Hopitable Genius <note n="" place="bottom">lingers harbours till,
To where the broken landcape, by degrees,
Acending, roughens into rigid ridgy hills;
O'er which the Cambrian mountains, like far clouds
That kirt the blue horion, duky doubtful, rie.
FLUSH'D by the pirit of the genial year,
Now from the virgin's cheek a freher bloom
Shoots, les and les, the live carnation round;
Her lips bluh deeper weets; he breathes of youth;
The hining moiture wells into her eyes,
In brighter flow; her wihing boom heaves,
With palpitations wild; kind tumults eize
Her veins, and all her yielding oul is love.
From the keen gaze her lover turns away,
Full of the dear ectatic power, and ick
With ighing languihment. Ah then, ye fair!
Be greatly cautious of your liding hearts:
Dare not th' infectious igh; the pleading look,
Down-cat, and low, in meek ubmiion dret,
But full of guile. Let not the fervent tongue,
Prompt to deceive, with adulation mooth,
Gain on your purpos'd will. Nor in the bower,
Where woodbines flaunt, and roes hed a couch,
While evening draws her crimon curtains round,
Trut your oft minutes with betraying Man.
AND let th' apiring youth beware of love,
Of the mooth glance beware for 'tis too late,
When on his heart the torrent-oftnes pours.
Then widom protrate lies, and fading fame
Diolves in air away; while the fond oul,
Wrapt in gay viions of unreal blis,
Still paints th' i • lu •• e form; the kindling grace;
Th' inticing mile the modet-eeming eye,
Beneath whoe beauteous beams, belying heaven,
Lurk earchles cunning, cruelty, and death:
And till, • a • -warb • ing in his cheated ear,
Her yren voice, enchanting, draws him on,
To guileful hores, and meads of fatal joy.
EVEN preent, in the very lap of love
Inglorious laid; while muic flows around,
Perfumes, and oils, and wine, and wanton hours;
Amid the roes fierce repentance rears
Her naky cret: a quick-returning pang
Shoots thro' the concious heart; where honour till,
And great deign, againt th' oppreive load
Of luxury, by fits, impatient heave.
BUT abent, what fantatic woes, arous'd,
Rage in each thought, by retles muing fed,
Chill the warm cheek, and blat the bloom of life?
Neglected fortune flies; and liding wift,
Prone into ruin, fall his corn'd affairs.
'Tis nought but gloom around. The darken'd un
Loes his light. The roy-boom'd pring
To weeping fancy pines; and you bright arch,
Contracted, bends into a duky vault.
All Nature fades extinct; and he alone
Heard, felt, and een, poees every thought,
Fills every ene, and pants in every vein.
Books are but formal dulnes, tedious friends,
And ad amid the ocial band he its;
Lonely, and unattentive. From his tongue
Th' unfinih'd period falls: while, borne away,
On welling thought, his wafted pirit flies
To the vain boom of his ditant fair;
And leaves the emblance of a lover, fix'd
In melancholy ite, with head declin'd,
And love-dejected eyes. Sudden he tarts,
Shook from his tender trance, and retles runs
To glimmering hades, and ympathetic glooms;
Where the dun umbrage o'er the falling tream,
Romantic, hangs; there thro' the penive duk
Strays, in heart-thrilling meditation lot,
Indulging all to love; or on the bank
Thrown, amid drooping lilies, wells the breeze
With ighs unceaing, and the brook with tears.
Thus in oft anguih he conumes the day,
Nor quits his deep retirement, till the moon
Peeps thro' the chambers of the fleecy eat,
Enlighten'd by degrees, and in her train
Leads on the gentle hours: then forth he walks,
Beneath the trembling languih of her beam,
With often'd oul, and wooes the bird of eve
To mingle woes with his: or, while the world
And all the ons of care lie huh'd in leep,
Aociates with the midnight hadows drear;
And, ighing to the lonely taper, pours
His idly-tortur'd heart into the page,
Meant for the moving meenger of love;
Where rapture burns on rapture, every line
With riing frenzy fir'd. But if on bed
Delirious flung, leep from his pillow flies.
All night he toes, nor the balmy power
In any poture finds; till the grey morn
Lifts her pale lutre on the paler wretch,
Exani • ate by love: and then perhaps
Exhauted Nature inks a while to ret,
Still interrupted by ditracted dreams
That o'er the ick imagination rie,
And in black colours paint the mimic cene.
Oft with th' enchantres of his oul he talks;
Sometimes in crouds ditres'd; or if retir'd
To ecret-winding flower-enwoven bowers
Far from the dull impertinence of Man,
Jut as he, credulous, his endles cares
Begins to loe in blind oblivious love,
Snatch'd from her yielded hand, he knows not how,
Thro' forets huge, and long untravel'd heaths
With deolation brown, he wanders wate,
In night and tempet wrapt; or hrinks aghat,
Back, from the bending precipice; or wades
The turbid tream below, and trives to reach
The farther hore; where uccourles, and ad,
She with extended arms his aid implores,
But trives in vain; borne by th' outrageous flood
To ditance down, he rides the ridgy wave,
Or whelm'd beneath the boiling eddy inks.
Thee are the charming agonies of love,
Whoe miery delights. But thro' the heart
Should jealouy its venom once diffue,
'Tis then delightful miery no more,
But agony unmix'd, inceant gall,
Corroding every thought, and blating all
Love's paradie. Ye fairy propects, then,
Ye beds of roes, and ye bowers of joy,
Farewel! Ye gleamings of departed departing peace,
Shine out your lat! the yellow-tinging plague
Internal viion taints, and in a night
Of livid gloom imagination wraps.
Ah then! intead of love-enliven'd cheeks,
Of unny features, and of ardent eyes
With flowing rapture bright, dark looks ucceed,
Suffus'd, and glaring with untender fire,
A clouded cloudy apect, and a burning cheek,
Where the whole poion'd oul, malignant its,
And frightens love away. Ten thouand fears
Invented wild, ten thouand frantic views
Of horrid rivals, hanging on the charms
For which he melts in fondnes, eat him up
With fervent anguih, and conuming rage.
In vain reproaches lend their idle aid,
Deceitful pride, and reolution frail,
Giving fale peace a moment. Fancy pours,
Afreh, her beauties on his buy thought,
Her firt endearments, twining round the oul,
With all the witchcraft of ennaring love.
Strait the fierce torm involves his mind anew,
Flames thro' the nerves, and boils along the veins:
While anxious doubt ditracts the tortur'd heart;
For even the ad aurance of his fears
Were eae peace to what he feels. Thus the warm youth
Whom love deludes into his thorny wilds,
Thro' flowery-tempting paths, or leads a life
Of fever'd rapture, or of cruel care;
His brightet aims extinguih'd all, and all
His lively moments running down to wate.
BUT happy they! the happiet of their kind!
Whom gentle tars unite, and in one fate
Their hearts, their fortunes, and their beings blend.
'Tis not the coarer tie of human laws,
Unnatural oft, and foreign to the mind,
That binds their peace, but harmony itelf,
Attuning all their paions into love;
Where friendhip full-exerts her oftet power,
Perfect eteem enliven'd by deire
Ineffable, and ympathy of oul;
Thought meeting thought, and will preventing will,
With boundles confidence: for nought but love
Can anwer love, and render blis ecure.
Let him, ungenerous, who, alone intent
To bles himelf, from ordid parents buys
The loathing virgin, in eternal care,
Well-merited, conume his nights and days:
Let barbarous nations, whoe inhuman love
Is wild deire, fierce as the uns they feel;
Let eatern tyrants from the light of heaven
Seclude their boom-laves, meanly poes'd
Of a meer, lifeles, violated form:
While thoe whom love cements in holy faith,
And equal tranport, free as Nature live,
Didaining fear. What is the world to them,
Its pomp, its pleaure, and its nonene all!
Who in each other clap whatever fair
High fancy forms, and lavih hearts can wih;
Something than beauty dearer, hould they look
Or on the mind, or mind-illumin'd face;
Truth, goodnes, honour, harmony, and love,
The richet bounty of indulgent HEAVEN.
Mean-time a miling offspring ries round,
And mingles both their graces. By degrees,
The human bloom blows; and every day,
Soft as it rolls along, hews ome new charm
The father's lutre, and the mother's bloom.
Then infant reaon grows apace, and calls
For the kind hand of an aiduous care.
Delightful tak! to rear the tender thought,
To teach the young idea how to hoot,
To pour the freh • ntruction o'er the mind,

To breath <>
• ivening pirit, and to fix
The gene • p • rpoe in the glowing breat.
Oh peak the joy,! ye, whom the udden tear
Surprizes often, while you look around,
And nothing trikes your eye but ights of blis,
All various Nature preing on the heart:
An elegant ufficiency, content,
Retirement, rural quiet, friendhip, books,
Eae and alternate labour, ueful life,
Progreive virtue, and approving HEAVEN.
Thee are the matchles joys of virtuous love;
And thus their moments fly. The eaons thus,
As ceaeles round a jarring world they roll,
Still find them happy; and conenting SPRING
Sheds her own roy garland on their heads:
Till evening comes at lat, erene and mild;
When after the long vernal day of life,
Enamour'd more, as more remembrance wells
With many a proof of recollected love,
Together down they ink in ocial leep;
Together freed, their gentle pirits fly
To cenes where love and blis immortal reign.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The ubject propoed. Invocation. Addres to Mr. DODINGTON. An introductory reflexion on the motion of the heavenly bodies; whence the ucceion of the eaons. As the face of Nature in this eaon is almot uniform, the progres of the poem is a decription of a ummer's day. The dawn. Sun-riing. Hymn to the un. Forenoon. Summer inects decrib'd. Hay-making. Sheep-hearing. Noon-day. A woodland retreat. Groupe of herds and flocks. A olemn grove: how it affects a contemplative mind. A cataract, and rude cene. View of ummer in the torrid zone. Storm of thunder and lightning. A tale. The torm over, a erene afternoon. Bathing. Hour of walking. Tranition to the propect of a rich well-cultivated country; which introduces a panegyric on GREAT BRITAIN. Sun-et. Evening. Night. Summer meteors. A comet. The whole concluding with the praie of philoophy.

lg.l: FROM brightening fields of ether fair diclos'd,
Child of the un, refulgent SUMMER comes,
In pride of youth, and felt thro' Nature's depth:
He comes attended by the ultry hours,
And ever-fanning breezes, on his way;
While, from his ardent look, the turning SPRING
Averts her bluhful face; and earth, and kies,
All-miling, to his hot dominion leaves.
HENCE, let me hate into the mid-wood hade,
Where carce a un-beam wanders thro' the gloom;
And on the dark-green gras, beide the brink
Of haunted tream, that by the roots of oak
Rolls o'er the rocky channel, lie at large,
And ing the glories of the circling year.
COME, Inpiration! from thy hermit-eat,
By mortal eldom found: may fancy dare,
From thy fix'd erious eye, and raptur'd glance
Shot on urrounding Heaven, to teal one look
Creative of the poet, every power
Exalting to an ectay of oul.
AND thou, my youthful Mue's early friend,
In whom the human graces all unite:
Pure light of mind, and tendernes of heart;
Genius, and widom; the gay ocial ene,
By decency chatis'd; goodnes and wit,
In eldom-meeting harmony combin'd;
Unblemih'd honour, and an active zeal,
For BRITAIN's glory, Liberty, and Man:
O DODINGTON! attend my rural ong,
Stoop to my theme, in pirit every line,
And teach me to deerve thy jut applaue.
WITH what an awful world-revolving power
Were firt th' unwieldy planets launch'd along
Th' illimitable void! Thus to remain
Amid the flux of many thouand years,
That oft has wept the toiling race of Men
And all their labour'd monuments away,
Firm, unremitting, matchles, in their coure;
To the kind-temper'd change of night and day,
And of the eaons ever tealing round,
Minutely faithful: Such TH' ALL PERFECT HAND! the perfect hand,
That pois'd, impels, and rules the teady WHOLE.
WHEN now no more th' alternate Twins are fir'd,
And Cancer reddens with the olar blaze,
Short is the doubtful empire of the night;
And oon, obervant of approaching day,
The meek-ey'd Morn appears, mother of dews,
At firt faint-gleaming in the dappled eat:
Till far o'er ether preads the widening glow;
And, from before the lutre of her face,
White break the clouds away. With quicken'd tep,
Brown Night retires. Young Day pours in apace,
And opens all the lawny propect wide.
The dripping rock, the mountain's mity top
Swell on the ight, and brighten with the dawn.
Blue, thro' the duk, the moking currents hine;
And from the bladed field the fearful hare
Limps, aukward: while along the foret-glade
The wild deer trip, and often turning gaze
At early paenger. Muic awakes,
The native voice of undiembled joy;
And thick around the woodland hymns arie.
Rous'd by the cock, the oon-clad hepherd leaves
His moy cottage, where with Peace he dwells;
And from the crouded fold, in order, drives
His flock, to tate the verdure of the morn.
FALSELY luxurious, will not Man awake;
And, pringing from the bed of loth, enjoy
The cool, the fragrant, and the ilent hour,
To meditation due, and acred ong?
For is there aught in leep can charm the wie?
To lie in dead oblivion, loing half
The fleeting moments of too hort a life?
Total extinction of th' enlighten'd oul;
Or ele to feverih vanity alive,
Wilder'd, and toing thro' ditemper'd dreams?
Who would in uch a gloomy tate remain
Longer than Nature craves; when every Mue
And every blooming pleaure wait without,
To bles the wildly-devious morning-walk?
BUT yonder comes the powerful King of Day,
Rejoicing in the eat. The leening cloud,
The kindling azure, and the mountain's brow
Illum'd with fluid gold, his near approach
Betoken glad. Lo! now, apparent all,
Alant the dew-bright earth, and colour'd air,
He looks in boundles majety abroad;
And heds the hining day, that burnih'd plays
On rocks, and hills, and towers, and wandering treams,
High-gleaming from afar. Prime chearer, light!
Of all material beings firt, and bet!
Efflux divine! Nature's replendent robe!
Without whoe veting beauty all were wrapt
In uneential gloom; and thou, O Sun!
Soul of urrounding worlds! in whom bet een
Shines out thy Maker! may I ing of thee?
'TIS by thy ecret, trong, attractive force,
As with a chain indioluble bound,
Thy Sytem rolls entire: from the far bourne
Of utmot Saturn, wheeling wide his round
Of thirty years; to Mercury, whoe dik
Can carce be caught by philoophic eye,
Lot in the near effulgence of thy blaze.
INFORMER of the planetary train!
Without whoe quickening glance their cumbrous orbs
Were brute unlovely mas, inert and dead,
And not as now the green abodes of life;
How many forms of being wait on thee
Inhaling pirit; from th' unfetter'd mind,
By thee ublim'd, down to the daily race,
The mixing myriads of thy etting beam.
THE vegetable world is alo thine,
Parent of Seaons! who the pomp precede
That waits thy throne, as thro' thy vat domain,
Annual, along the bright ecliptic road,
In world-rejoicing tate, it moves ublime.
Mean-time th' expecting nations, circled gay
With all the various tribes of foodful earth,
Implore thy bounty, or end grateful up
A common hymn: while, round thy beaming car,
High-een, the Seaons lead, in prightly dance
Harmonious knit, the roy-finger'd Hours,
The Zephyrs floating looe, the timely Rains,
Of bloom ethereal the light-footed Dews,
And often'd into joy the urly Storms.
Thee, in ucceive turn, with lavih hand,
Shower every beauty, every fragrance hower,
Herbs, flowers, and fruits; till, kindling at thy touch,
From land to land is fluh'd the vernal year.
NOR to the urface of enlivened earth,
Graceful with hills and dales, and leafy woods,
Her liberal trees, is thy force confin'd:
But, to the bowel'd cavern darting deep,
The mineral kinds confes thy mighty power.
Effulgent, hence the veiny marble hines;
Hence Labour draws his tools; hence burnih'd War
Gleams on the day; the nobler works of Peace
Hence bles mankind, and generous Commerce binds
The round of nations in a golden chain.
THE unfruitful rock itelf, impregn'd by thee,
In dark retirement, forms the lucid tone.
The lively Diamond drinks thy puret rays,
Collected light, compact; that, polih'd bright,
And all its native lutre let abroad,
Dares, as it parkles on the fair one's breat,
With vain ambition emulate her eyes.
At thee the Ruby lights its deepning glow,
And with a waving radiance inward flames.
From thee the apphire, olid ether, takes
Its hue cerulean; and, of evening tinct,
The purple-treaming Amethyt is thine.
With thy own mile the yellow topaz burns.
Nor deeper verdure dyes the robe of Spring,
When firt he gives it to the outhern gale,
Than the green Emerald hows. But, all combin'd,
Thick thro' the whitening Opal play thy beams;
Or, flying everal from its urface, form
A trembling variance of revolving hues,
As the ite varies in the gazer's hand.
THE very dead creation, from thy touch,
Aumes a mimic life. By thee refin'd,
In brighter mazes, the relucent tream
Plays o'er the mead. The precipice abrupt,
Projecting horror on the blacken'd flood,
Softens at thy return. The deart joys
Wildly, thro' all his melancholy bounds.
Rude ruins glitter; and the briny deep,
Seen from ome pointed promontory's top,
Far to the blue horizon's utmot verge,
Retles, reflects a floating gleam. But this,
And all the much-tranported Mue can ing,
Are to thy beauty, dignity, and ue,
Unequal far, great delegated ource,
Of light, and life, and grace, and joy below!
HOW hall I then attempt to ing of HIM,
Who, LIGHT HIMSELF, in uncreated light
Inveted deep, dwells awfully retir'd
From mortal eye, or angel's purer ken;
Whoe ingle mile has, from the firt of time,
Fill'd, overflowing, all thoe lamps of heaven,
That beam for ever, thro' the boundles ky:
But, hould he hide his face, th' atonih'd un,
And all th' extinguih'd tars, would looening reel tart
Wide from their pheres, and Chaos come again.
AND yet was every faultering tongue of Man,
ALMIGHTY FATHER MAKER! ilent in thy praie;

In folds looe-floating fell the fainter lawn;
And fair-expos'd he tood, hrunk from herelf
With fancy bluhing, at the doubtful breeze
Alarm'd, and tarting like the fearfu • fawn?
Then to the flood he ruh'd; the parted flood
Its lovely guet with cloing waves receiv'd;
And every beauty oftening, every grace
Fluhing anew, a mellow lutre hed:
As hines the lily thro' the chrytal mild;
Or as the roe amid the morning dew,
Freh from Aurora's hand, more weetly glows.
While thus he wanton'd, now beneath the wave
But ill-conceal'd; and now with treaming locks,
That half-embrac'd her in a humid veil,
Riing again, the latent DAMON drew
Such madning draughts of beauty to the oul.
As for a while o'erwhelm'd his raptur'd thought
With luxury too daring. Check'd, at lat,
By love's repectful modety, he deem'd.
The theft profane, if aught profane to love
Can e'er be deem'd; and, truggling from the hade,
With headlong hurry fled; but firt thee lines,
Trac'd by his ready pencil, on the bank
With trembling hand he threw. "Bathe on, my fair,
"Yet unbeheld ave by the acred eye
"Of faithful love. I go to guard thy haunt,
"To keep from thy reces each vagrant foot,
"And each licentious eye." With wild urprize,
As if to marble truck, devoid of ene,
A tupid moment motionles he tood:
So •• ands the The Venus of Medici. tatue that enchants the world,
So bending tries to veil the matchles boat,
The mingled beauties of exulting Greece.
Recovering, wift he flew to find thoe robes
Which blisful Eden knew not; and, array'd

But when her DAMON's well-known hand he aw,
Her terrors vanih'd, and a ofter train
Of mix'd emotions, hard to be decrib'd,
Her udden boom eiz'd: hame void of guilt,
The charming bluh of innocence, eteem
And admiration of her lover's flame,
By modety exalted: even a ene
Of elf-approving beauty tole acros

And on the preading beach, that o'er the tream

"Alas! not favour'd les, be till as now

THE un has lot his rage: his downward orb
Shoots nothing now but animating warmth,
And vital lutre; that, with various ray,
Lights up the clouds, thoe beauteous robes of heaven,
Inceant roll'd into romantic hapes,
The dream of waking fancy! Broad below,
Cover'd with ripening fruits, and welling fat
Into the perfect year, the pregnant earth
And all her tribes rejoice. Now the oft hour
Of walking comes: for him who lonely loves
To eek the ditant hills, and there convere
With Nature; there to harmonize his heart,
And in pathetic ong to breathe around
The harmony to others. Social friends,
Attun'd to happy union of oul;
To whoe exalting eye a fairer world,
Of which the vulgar never had a glimpe,
Diplays its charms; whoe minds are richly fraught
With philoophic tores, uperior light;
And in whoe breat, enthuiatic, burns
Virtue, the ons of interet deem romance;
Now call'd abroad enjoy the falling day
Now to the verdant Portico of woods,
By that kind School where no proud mater reigns,
The full free convere of the friendly heart
Improving and improv'd. Now from the world,
Sacred to weet retirement, lovers teal,
And pour their ouls in tranport, which the SIRE
Of love approving hears, and calls it good.
Which way, AMANDA, hall we bend our coure?
The choice perplexes. Wherefore hould we chue?
All is the ame with thee. Say, hall we wind
Along the treams? or walk the miling mead?
Or court the foret-glades? or wander wild
Among the waving harvets? or acend,
While radiant Summer opens all its pride,

Shene? Here let us weep
The boundles landkip: now the raptur'd eye,
Exulting wift, to huge AUGUSTA end,

Now, to the High-gate and Hamtead
Siter-hills that kirt her plain,
To lofty Harrow now, and now to where
Majetic Windor lifts his princely brow.
In lovely contrat to this glorious view,
Calmly magnificent, then will we turn
To where the ilver THAMES firt rural grows.
There let the feated eye unweary'd tray:
Luxurious, there, rove thro' the pendan • woods
That nodding hang o'er HARRINGTON's retreat;
And, tooping thence to Ham's embowering walks,
Beneath whoe hades, in potles peace retir'd,
With HER the pleaing partner of his heart,
The worthy QUEENSB'RY yet laments his GAY,
And polih'd CORNBURY wooes the willing mue,
Slow let us trace the matchles VALE OF THAMES;
Fair-winding up to where the Mues haunt
In Twi • nam's bowers, and for their POPE implore
The healing God In his lat icknes., to royal Hampton's pile,
To Clermont's terras'd height, and F • her's groves,
Where in the weetet olitude, embrac'd
By the oft windings of the ilent Mole,
From courts and enates PELHAM finds Repoe.
Inchanting vale! beyond whate'er the Mue
Has of Achaia or Heperia ung!
O vale of blis! O oftly-welling hills!
On which the Power of Cultivation lies,
And joys to ee the wonders of his toil.
HEAVENS! what a goodly propect preads around
Of hills, and dales, and woods, and lawn • , and pires,
And glittering towns, and gilded treams, till all
The tretching landkip into moke decays!
Happy BRITANNIA! where the QUEEN OF ARTS,
Inpiring vigour, LIBERTY abroad
Walks, unconfin'd, even to thy farthet cotts,
And catters plenty with unparing hand.
RICH is thy oil, and merciful thy clime;
Thy treams unfailing in the ummer's drought;
Unmatch'd thy guardian-oaks; thy vallies float
With golden waves: and on thy mountains flocks
Bleat numberles; while, roving round their ides,
Bellow the blackening herds in luty droves.
Beneath, thy meadows glow, and rie unquell'd
Againt the mower's cythe. On every hand,
Thy villas hine. Thy country teems with wealth;
And property aures it to the wain,
Pleas'd, and unweary'd, in his guarded toil.
FULL are thy cities with the ons of art;
And trade and joy, in every buy treet,
Mingling are heard: even Drudgery himelf,
As at the car he weats, or duty hews
The palace-tone, looks gay. Thy crowded ports,
Where riing mats an endles propect yield,
With labour burn, and echo to the houts
Of hurry'd ailor, as he hearty waves
His lat adieu, and looening every heet,
Reigns the preading veel to the wind.
BOLD, firm, and graceful, are thy generous youth,
By hardhip inew'd, and by danger fir'd,
Scattering the nations where they go; and firt
Or on the lited plain, or tormy wintry eas.
Mild are thy glories too, as o'er the plans
Of thriving peace thy thoughtful fires preide;
In genius, and ubtantial learning, high;
For every virtue, every worth renown'd;
Sincere, plain-hearted, hopitable, kind;
Yet like the mutering thunder when provok'd,
The dread of tyrants, and the ole reource
Of thoe that under grim oppreion groan.
THY SONS OF GLORY many! ALFRED thine,
In whom the plendor of heroic war,
And more heroic peace, when govern'd well,
Combine; whoe hallow'd name the virtues aint
And his own Mues love, the bet of Kings.
With him thy EDWARDS and thy HENRY's hine
Names dear to fame; the firt who deep impres'd
On haughty Gaul the terror of thy arms,
That awes her genius till. In Statemen thou,
And Patriots, fertile. Thine a teady MORE,
Who, with a generous tho' mitaken zeal,
Withtood a brutal tyrant's ueful rage,
Like CATO firm, like ARISTIDES jut,
Like rigid CINCINNATUS nobly poor,
A dauntles oul erect, who mil'd on death.
Frugal, and wie, a WALSINGHAM is thine;
A DRAKE, who made thee mitres of the deep,
And bore thy name in thunder round the world
Then flam'd thy pirit high: but who can peak
The numerous worthies of the MAIDEN REIGN?
In RALEIGH mark their every glory mix'd,
RALEIGH, the courge of Spain! whoe breat with all
The age, the patriot, and the hero burn'd.
Nor unk his vigour, when a coward-reign
The warrior • etter'd, and at lat reign'd,
To glut the vengeance of a vanquih'd foe.
Then, active till and unretrain'd, his mind
Explor'd the vat extent of ages pat,
And with his prion hours enrich'd the world;
Yet found no times, in all the long reearch,
So glorious, or o bae, as thoe he prov'd,
In which he conquer'd, and in which he bled.
Nor can the Mue the gallant SIDNEY pas,
The plume of war! with early lawrels crown'd,
The Lover's myrtle, and the Poet's bay.
A HAMPDEN too is thine, illutrious land,
Wie, trenuous, firm, of unubmitting oul,
Who tem'd the torrent of a downward age
To lavery prone, and bade thee rie again,
In all thy native pomp of freedom bold.
Bright, at his call, thy age of Men effulg'd,
Of Men on whom late time a kindling eye
Shall turn, and tyrants tremble while they read.
Bring every weetet flower, and let me trow
The grave where RUSSEL lies; whoe temper'd blood
With calmet chearfulnes for thee reign'd,
Stain'd the ad annals of a giddy reign;
Aiming at lawles power, tho' meanly unk
In looe inglorious luxury. With him
His friend, the ALCERMON SIDNEY. BRITISH CASSIUS, fearles bled;
Of high determin'd pirit, roughly brave,
By antient learning to th' enlighten'd love
Of antient freedom warm'd. Fair thy renown
In awful Sages and in noble Bards;
Soon as the light of dawning cience pread
Her orient ray, and wak'd the Mues' ong.
Thine is a BACON; haples in his choice,
Unfit to tand the civil torm of tate,
And thro' the mooth barbarity of courts.
With firm but pliant virtue, forward till
To urge his coure. Him for the tudious hade
Kind Nature form'd, deep, comprehenive, clear,
Exact, and elegant; in one rich oul,
PLATO, the STAGYRITE, and TULLY join'd.
The great deliverer he! who from the gloom
Of cloyter'd monks, and jargon-teaching chools,
Led forth the true Philoophy, there long
Held in the magic chain of words and forms,
And definitions void: he led her forth,
Daughter of HEAVEN! that, low-acending till,
Invetigating ure the chain of things,
With radiant finger points to HEAVEN again.
The generous ANTHONY ASHLEY COOPER, Earl of Shaftebury. ASHLEY thine, the friend of Man;
Who cann'd his Nature with a brother's eye,
His weaknes prompt to hade, to raie his aim,
To touch the finer movements of the mind,
And with the moral beauty charm the heart.
Why need I name thy BOYLE, whoe pious earch
A mid the dark recees of his works,
The great CREATOR ought? And why thy LOCKE,
Who made the whole internal world his own?
Let NEWTON, pure Intelligence, whom GOD
To mortals lent, to trace his boundles works
From laws ublimely imple, peak thy fame
In all philoophy. For lofty ene,
Creative fancy, and inpection keen
Thro' the deep windings of the human heart,
Is not wild SHAKESPEAR thine and Nature's boat?
Is not each great, each amiable Mue
Of claic ages in thy MILTON met?
A genius univeral as his Theme,
Atonihing as Chaos, as the bloom
Of blowing Eden fair, as Heaven ublime.
Nor hall my vere that elder bard forget,
The gentle SPENSER, Fancy's pleaing on;
Who, like a copious river, pour'd his ong
O'er all the mazes of enchanted ground:
Nor thee, his antient mater, laughing age,
CHAUCER, whoe native manners-painting vere,
Well-moraliz'd, hines thro' the Gothic cloud
Of time and language o'er thy genius thrown.
MAY my ong often, as thy DAUGHTERS I,
BRITANNIA, hail! for beauty is their own,
The feeling heart, implicity of life,
And elegance, and tate: the faultles form,
Shap'd by the hand of harmony; the cheek,
Where the live crimon, through the native white
Soft-hooting o'er the face diffues bloom,
And every nameles grace; the parted lip,
Like the red roe bud moit with morning-dew,
Breathing delight; and, under flowing jet,
Or unny ringlets, or of circling brown,
The neck light-haded, and the welling breat;
The look reitles, piercing to the oul,
And by the oul inform'd, when dret in love
She its high-miling in the concious eye.
ISLAND of blis! amid the ubject eas,
That thunder round thy rocky coats, et up,
At once the wonder, terror, and delight,
Of ditant nations; whoe remotet hores
Can oon be haken by thy naval arm,
Not to be hook thy elf, but all aaults
Baffling, as like thy hoar cliffs the loud ea-wave.
O THOU! by whoe almighty Nod the cale
Of empire ries, or alternate falls,
Send forth the aving VIRTUES round the land,
In bright patrol: white Peace, and ocial Love;
The tender-looking Charity, intent
On gentle deeds, and hedding tears thro' miles;
Undaunted Truth, and Dignity of mind;
Courage compos'd, and keen; ound Temperance
Healthful in heart and look; clear Chatity,
With bluhes reddening as he moves along,
Diorder'd at the deep regard he draws;
Rough Indutry; Activity untir'd,
With copious life inform'd, and all awake:
While, in the radiant front, uperior hines
That firt paternal virtue, Public Zeal,
Who throws o'er all an equal wide urvey,
And, ever muing on the common weal,
Still labours glorious with ome great deign.
LOW walks the un, and broadens by degrees,
Jut o'er the verge of day. The hifting clouds
Aembled gay, a richly-gorgeous train,
In all their pomp attend his etting throne.
Air, earth, and ocean mile immene. And now,
As if his weary chariot ought the bowers
Of Amphitritè, and her tending nymphs,
(So Grecian fable ung) he dips his orb;
Now half-immers'd; and now a golden curve
Gives one bright glance, then total diappears.
FOR ever running an enchanted round,
Paes the day, deceitful, vain, and void;
As fleets the viion o'er the formful brain,
This moment hurrying wild th' impaion'd oul,
The next in nothing lot. 'Tis o to him,
The dreamer of this earth, an idle blank:
A ight of horror to the cruel wretch,
Who all day long in ordid pleaure roll'd,
Himelf an ueles load, has quander'd vile,
Upon his coundrel train, what might have cheer'd
A drooping family of modet worth.
But to the generous till-improving mind,
That gives the hopeles heart to ing for joy,
Diffuing kind beneficence around,
Boatles, as now decends the ilent dew;
To him the long review of order'd life
Is inward rapture, only to be felt.
CONFESS'd from yonder low-extinguih'd clouds,
All ether oftening, ober Evening takes
Her wonted tation in the middle air;
A thouand Shadows at her beck. Firt this
She ends on earth; then that of deeper dye
Steals oft behind; and then a deeper till,
In circle following circle, gathers round,
To cloe the face of things. A freher gale
Begins to wave the wood, and tir the tream,
Sweeping with hadowy gut the fields of corn;
While the quail clamours for his running mate.
Wide o'er the thitly lawn, as wells the breeze,
A whitening hower of vegetable down
Amuive floats. The kind impartial care
Of Nature nought didains: thoughtful to eed
Her lowet ons, and clothe the coming year,
From field to field the feather'd eeds he wings.
HIS folded flock ecure, the hepherd home
Hies, merry-hearted; and by turns relieves
The ruddy milk-maid of her brimming pail;
The beauty whom perhaps his witles heart,
Unknowing what the joy-mix'd anguih means,
Sincerely loves, by that bet language hewn
Of cordial glances, and obliging deeds.
Onward they pas, o'er many a panting height,
And valley unk, and unfrequented; where
At fall of eve the fairy people throng,
In various game, and revelry to pas
The ummer-night, as village-tories tell.
But far about they wander from the grave
Of him, whom his ungentle fortune urg'd
Againt his own ad breat to lift the hand
Of impious violence. The lonely tower
I • alo hunn'd; whoe mournful chambers hold,
So night-truck fancy dreams, the yelling ghot.
AMONG the crooked lanes on every hedge,
The glow-worm lights his gem; and, thro' the dark,
A moving radiance twinkles. Evening yields
The world to Night; not in her winter-robe
Of may tygian woof, but looe array'd
In mantle dun. A faint erroneous ray,
Glanc'd from th'imperfect urfaces of things,
Flings half an image on the training eye;
While wavering woods, and villages, and treams,
And rocks, and mountain-tops, that long retain'd
Th' acending gleam, are all one wimming cene,
Uncertain if beheld. Sudden to heaven
Thence weary viion turns; where, leading oft
The ilent hours of love, with puret ray
Sweet Venus hines; and from her genial rie,
When day-light ickens till it prings afreh,
Unrival'd reigns, the fairet lamp of night,
As thus th' effulgence tremulous I drink,
With cherih'd gaze, the lambent lightnings hoot
Acros the ky; or horizontal dart,
In wondrous hapes: by fearful murmuring crowds
Portentous deem'd. Amid the radiant orbs,
That more than deck, that animate the ky,
The life-infuing uns of other worlds;
Lo! from the dread immenity of pace
Returning, with accelerated coure,
The ruhing comet to the un decends;
And as he inks below the hading earth,
With awful train projected o'er the heavens,
The guilty nations tremble. But, above
Thoe upertitious horrors that enlave
The fond equacious herd, to mytic faith
And blind amazement prone, th' enlighten'd few,
Whoe godlike minds philoophy exalts,
The glorious tranger hail. They feel a joy
Divinely great; they in their powers exult,
That wondrous force of thought, which mounting purns
This duky pot, and meaures all the ky;
While, from his far excurion thro' the wilds
Of barren aether, faithful to his time,
They ee the blazing wonder rie anew,
In eeming terror clad, but kindly bent
To work the will of all-utaining LOVE:
From his huge vapoury train perhaps to hake
Reviving moiture on the numerous orbs,
Thro' which his long ellipis winds; perhaps
To lend new fuel to declining uns,
To light up worlds, and feed th' eternal fire.
WITH thee, erene PHILOSOPHY! with thee,
And thy bright garland, let me crown my ong!
Effuive ource of evidence, and truth!
A lutre hedding o'er th' ennobled mind.
Stronger than ummer-noon; and pure as that,
Whoe mild vibrations oothe the parted oul,
New to the dawning of celetial day.
Hence thro' her nourih'd powers, enlarg'd by thee;
She prings aloft, with elevated pride,
Above the tangling mas of low deires,
That bind the fluttering crowd; and, angel-wing'd,
The heights of cience and of virtue gains,
Where all is calm and clear; with Nature round
Or in the tarry regions, or th' abys,
To reaon's and to fancy's eye diplay'd:
The Firt up-tracing, from the dreary void,
The chain of caues and effects to HIM,
The world-producing ESSENCE, who alone
Poees being; while the Lat receives
The whole magnificence of heaven and earth,
And every beauty, delicate or bold,
Obvious or more remote, with livelier ene,
Diffuive painted on the rapid mind.
TUTOR'D by thee, hence POETRY exalts
Her voice to ages; and informs the page
With muic, image, entiment, and thought,
Never to die! the treaure of mankind!
Their highet honour, and their truet joy!
WITHOUT thee what were unenlighten'd Man?
A avage roaming thro' the woods and wilds,
In quet of prey; and with th' unfahion'd furr
Rough-clad; devoid of every finer art,
And elegance of life. Nor happines
Dometic, mix'd of tendernes and care,
Nor moral excellence, nor ocial blis,
Nor guardian law were his; nor various kill
To turn the furrow, or to guide the tool
Mechanic; nor the heaven-conducted prow
Of navigation bold, that fearles braves
The burning line, or dares the wint'ry pole;
Mother evere of infinite delights!
Nothing, ave rapine, indolence, and guile,
And woes on woes, a till-revolving train!
Whoe horrid circle had made human life
Than non-exitence wore: but, taught by thee,
Ours are the plans of policy, and peace;
To live like brothers, and conjunctive all
Embellih life. While thus laborious crowds
Ply the tough oar, PHILOSOPHY directs
The ruling helm; or like the liberal breath
Of potent Heaven, inviible, the ail
Swells out, and bears th' inferior world along.
NOR to this evanecent peck of earth
Poorly confin'd, the radiant tracts on high
Are her exalted range; intent to gaze
Creation thro'; and, from that full complex
Of never-ending wonders, to conceive
Of the SOLE BEING right, who poke the Word,
And Nature mov'd compleat. With inward view,
Thence on th' ideal kingdom wift he turns
Her eye; and intant, at her powerful glance,
Th' obedient phantoms vanih or appear;
Compound, divide, and into order hift,
Each to his rank, from plain perception up
To the fair forms of Fancy's fleeting train:
This line not in the econd Edition. To Reaon then, deducing truth from truth;
And notion quite abtract; where firt begins
The world of pirits, action all, and life
Unfetter'd, and unmix'd. But here the cloud,
So wills ETERNAL PROVIDENCE, its deep.
Enough for us to know that this dark tate,
In wayward paions lot, and vain puruits,
This infancy of being, cannot prove
The final iue of the works of GOD,
By boundles LOVE and perfect WISDOM form'd,
And ever riing with the riing mind.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The ubject propoed. Addreed to Mr ONSLOW. A propect of the fields ready for harvet. Reflections in praie of indutry rais'd by that view. Reaping. A tale relative to it. A harvet-torm. Shooting and hunting, their barbarity. A ludicrous account of fox-hunting. A view of an orchard. Wall-fruit. A vineyard. A decription of fogs, frequent in the latter part of Autumn: whence a digreion, enquiring into the rie of fountains and rivers. Birds of eaon conidered, that now hift their habitation. The prodigious number of them that cover the northern and wetern iles of SCOTLAND. Hence a view of the country. A propect of the dicoloured, fading woods. After a gentle duky day, moon-light. Autumnal meteors. Morning: to which ucceeds a calm, pure, un-hiny day, uch as uually huts up the eaon. The harvet being gathered in, the country diolved in joy. The whole concludes with a panegyric on a philoophical country life.

lg.l: CROWN'D with the ickle and the wheaten heaf,
While AUTUMN, nodding o'er the yellow plain,
Comes jovial on; the Doric reed once more,
Well pleas'd, I tune. Whate'er the Wint'ry frot
Nitrous prepar'd; the various-bloom'd Spring
Put in white promie forth; and Summer-uns
Concocted trong, ruh boundles now to view,
Full, perfect all, and well my glorious theme.
ONSLOW! the Mue, ambitious of thy name,
To grace, inpire, and dignify her ong,
Would from the Public Voice thy gentle ear
A-while engage. Thy noble cares he knows,
The patriot virtues that ditend thy thought,
Spread on thy front, and in thy boom glow;
While litening enates hang upon thy tongue,
Devolving thro' the maze of eloquence
A roll of periods, weeter than her ong.
But he too pants for public virtue; he,

Tho' weak i •
of power, yet trong in ardent will,
Whene'er her country ruhes on her heart,
Aumes a bolder note, and fondly tries
To mix the patriot's with the poet's flame.
WHEN the bright Virgin gives the beauteous days,
And Libra weighs in equal cales the year;
From heaven's high cope the fierce effulgence hook
Of parting ummer, a erener blue,
With golden light enliven'd, wide invets
The happy world. Attemper'd uns arie,
Sweet-beam'd, and hedding oft thro' lucid clouds
A pleaing calm; while broad, and brown, below,
Extenive harvets hang the heavy head.
Rich, ilent, deep, they tand; for not a gale
Rolls its light billows o'er the bending plain;
A calm of plenty! till the ruffled air
Falls from its poie, and gives the breeze to blow.
Rent is the fleecy mantle of the ky;
The clouds fly different; and the udden un
By fits effulgent gilds th' illumin'd field,
And black by fits the hadows weep along
A gayly-checker'd heart-expanding view,
Far as the circling eye can hoot around,
Unbounded toing in a flood of corn.
THESE are thy bleings, INDUSTRY! rough power!
Whom labour till attends, and weat, and pain;
Yet the kind ource of every gentle art,
And all the oft civility of life;
Raier of human kind! by Nature cat,
Naked, and helples, out amid the woods,
And wilds, to rude inclement elements;
With various eeds of art deep in the mind
Implanted, and profuely pour'd around
Materials infinite; but idle all.
Still unexerted, in th' unconcious breat,
Slept the lethargic powers; corruption till,
Voracious, wallow'd what the liberal hand
Of bounty catter'd o'er the avage year:
And till the ad barbarian, roving, mix'd
With beats of prey; or for his acorn-meal
Fought the fierce tuky boar; a hivering wretch!
Aghat, and comfortles, when the bleak north,
With Winter charg'd, let the mix'd tempet fly,
Hail, rain, and now, and bitter-breathing frot:
Then to the helter of the hut he fled:
And the wild eaon, ordid, pin'd away.
For home he had not; home is the reort
Of love, of joy, of peace and plenty, where,
Supporting and upported, polih'd friends,
And dear relations mingle into blis.
But this the rugged avage never felt,
Even deolate in crowds; and thus his days,
Roll'd heavy, dark, and unenjoy'd along;
A wate of time! till INDUSTRY approach'd,
And rous'd him from his mierable loth:
His faculties unfolded; pointed out,
Where lavih Nature the directing hand
