Drinks the pure pleaures of the RURAL LIFE.
What tho' the dome be wanting, whoe proud gate,
Each morning, vomits out the neaking croud
Of flatterers fale, and in their turn abus'd?
Vile intercoure! What tho' the glittering robe
Of every hue reflected light can give,
Or floating looe, or tiff with mazy gold,
The pride and gaze of fools! oppres him not?
What tho', from utmot land and ea purvey'd
For him each rarer tributary life
Bleeds not, and his inatiate table heaps
With luxury and death? What tho' his bowl
Flames not with cotly juice, nor unk in beds,
Oft of gay care, he toes out the night,
Or melts the thoughtles hours in idle tate?
What tho' he knows not thoe fantatic joys
That till amue the wanton, till deceive;
A face of pleaure, but a heart of pain
Their hollow moments undelighted all?
Sure peace is his; a olid life, etrang'd
To diappointment, and fallacious hope:
Rich in content, in Nature's bounty rich,
In herbs and fruits; whatever greens the Spring,
When Heaven decends in howers; or bends the bough
Or in the wint'ry glebe whatever lies
Conceal'd, and fatte • s with the richet ap:
Thee are not wanting: nor the milky drove,
Luxuriant, pread o'er all the lowing vale;
Nor bleating mountains; nor the chide of treams,
And hum of bees, inviding le • p incere
Into the guiltles breat, beneath the hade,
Nor aught beides of propect, grove, or ong,
Dim grotto • s, gleaming lakes, and fountain clear.
Here too dwells imple truth; plain innocence;
Unullied beauty; ound unbroken youth,
Patient of labour, with a little pleas'd;
Health ever-blooming; unambitious toil;
Calm contemplation, and poetic eae.
Let others brave the flood in quet of gain,
And beat for joyles months, the gloomy wave
Let uch as deem it glory to detroy,
Ruh into blood, the ack of cities eek;
Unpierc'd, exulting in the widow's wail,
The virgin's hriek, the infant's trembling cry.
Let ome, far ditant from ther native oil,
Urg'd or by want, or hardened avarice,
Find other lands beneath another un.
Let this thro' cities work his eager way,
By legal outrage and etablih'd guile,
The ocial ene extinct; and that ferment
Mad into tumult the editious herd,
Or melt them down to lavery. Let thee
Innare the wretched in the toils of law,
Fomenting dicord, and perplexing right,
An iron race! and thoe of fairer front,
But equal inhumanity, in courts,
Deluive pomp, and dark cabals, delight:
Wreathe the deep brow diffue the lying mile,
And tread the weary labyrinth of tate.
While he, from all the tormy paions free
That retles men involve, hears, and but hears,
At ditance afe, the human tempet roar,
Wrapt cloe in concious peace. The fall of kings,
The rage of nations, and the cruh of tates
Move not the man, who from the world ecap'd
In till retreats, and flowery olitudes,
To Nature's voice attends, from month to month,
And day to day, thro' the revolving year;
Admiring ees her in her every hape,
Feels all her weet emotions at his heart;
Takes what he liberal gives, nor thinks of more.
He, when young Spring protrudes the burting gems,
Marks the firt bud, and ucks the healthful gale
Into his frehen'd oul; her genial hours
He full enjoys; and not a beauty blows,
And not an opening bloom breathes in vain.
In Summer he, beneath the living hade,
Such as o'er frigid Tempe wont to wave,
Or Hemus cool, reads what the Mue of th • e
Perhaps, has in immortal numbers ung;
Or what he dictates writes: and, oft an eye
Shot round, rejoices in the vigorous year.
When Autumn's yellow lutre gilds the world,
And tempts the fickled wain into the field;
Se • z'd by the general joy, his heart ditends
With gentle throes; and thro' the tepid gleams
Deep-muing, then he bet exerts his ong.
Even winter wild to him is full of blis.
The mighty tempet and the hoary wate,
Abrupt, and deep, tretch'd o'er the buried earth,
Awake to olemn thought. At night the kies,
Diclos'd, and k • ndled, by refining frot,
Pour ev'ry lutre on th' exalted eye.
A friend, a book, the tealing hours ecure,
And mark them down for widom. With wift wing,
O'er land and ea imagination roams;
Or truth, divinely breaking on his mind,
Ela • es his being, and unfolds his powers.
Or in his breat heroic virtue burns.
The modet eye, whoe beams on his alone
Ectatic hine; the little trong embrace
Of prattling children, twin'd around his neck,
And emulous to pleae him, calling forth
The fond parental oul. Nor purpoe gay,
Amuement, dance, or ong, he ternly corns;
For happines and true philoophy
Are of the ocial till, and miling kind.
This is the life which thoe who fret in guilt.
And guilty cities, never knew; the life
Led by primeval ages, uncorrupt,
When angels dwelt, and GOD himelf, with man!
Oh NATURE! all-ufficient! over all!
Enrich me with the knowledge of thy works!
Snatch me to heaven; thy rolling wonders there,
World beyond world, in infinite extent,
Profuely cattered o'er the blue immene,
Shew me; their motions, periods, and their laws,
Give me to can; thro' the dicloing deep
Light my blind way: the mineral trata there,
Thrut, blooming, thence the vegetable world;
O'er that the riing ytem, more complex,
Of an • mals; and higher till the mind,
The varied cene of quick-compounded thought,
And where the mixing paions endles hift;
Thee ever open to my ravih'd eye;
A earch the fl • ght of time can n'er exhaut?
But if to that unequal; if the blood,
In luggih treams about my heart, forbid
That bet ambition; under cloing hades,
In glorious lay me by the lowly brook,
And whiper to my dreams. From THEE begin,
Dwell all on THEE, with THEE conclude my ong;
And let me never, never tray from THEE!

div.head: WINTER.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The ubject propoed. Addres to the Earl ef WILMINGTON. Firt approach of Winter. According to the natural coure of the eaon, various torms decribed. Rain. Wind. Snow. The driving of the nows: A Man perihing among them; whence reflections on the wants and mieries of human life. The wolves decending from the Alps and Appenines. A wintry evening decribed; as pent by philoophers; by the country people; in the city Frot. A view of Winter within the polar circle. A thaw. The whole concluding with moral reflexions on a future tate.

div.head: WINTER.
div.l: SEE, WINTER comes, to rule the varied year,
Sullen, and ad, with all his riing train;
Vapours, and Clouds, and Storms. Be thee my theme,
Thee, that exalt my oul to olemn thought,
And heavenly muing. Welcome, kindred glooms!
Congenial horrors, hail! with frequent foot,
Pleas'd have I, in my chearful morn of life,
When nurs'd by careles olitude I liv'd,
And ung of Nature with unceaing joy,
Pleas'd have I wander'd thro' the rough domain;
Trod the pure virgin-nows, myelf as pure;
Heard the winds roar, and the big torrent burt;
Or een the deep fermenting tempet brew'd,
In the grim-evening ky Thus pas'd the time,
Till thro' the lucid chambers of the outh
Look'd out the joyous SPRING, look'd out and mil'd.
To thee, the patron of her firt eay,
The Mue, O WILMINGTON! renews her ong.
Since has he rounded the revolving year:
Skimm'd the gay Spring; on eagle-pinions borne,
Attempted thro' the Summer-blaze to rie;
Then wept o'er Autumn with the hadowy gale;
And now among the wint'ry clouds again,
Roll'd in the doubling torm, he tries to oar;
To well her no • e w • th all the ruhing winds;
To uit her ounding cadence to the floods;
As in her theme, her numbers wildly great:
Thrice happy! could he fill thy judging ear
With bold decription, and with manly thought.

Nor art thou kill •
• n awful chemes alone,
And how to m •• e a mighty people thrive:
But equal • oodnes, ound integrity,
A f •• m • haken uncorrupted oul
Ami •• liding age, and burning trong,
Not vainly blazing for thy country's weal,
A teady pirit regularly free;
Thee, each exalting each, the tateman light
Into the patriot; thee, the public hope
And eye to thee converting, bid the Mue
••• ord what envy dares not flattery call.
Now when the chearles empire of the ky
To Capricorn the C • ntaur Archer yield • ,
And fierce Aquarius tains th'inver • ed year.
Hung o'er the farthet ve • ge of heaven, the un
Scarce preads o'er aether the deje • ted day.
Faint are his gleams, and ineffectual hoot
His truggling rays, in horizontal lines,
Thro' the thick air as cloath'd in cloudy torm.
Weak, wan, and broad, he kirts the outhern ky;
And, oon decending, to the long dark night
•• de hading all, the protrate world reign • .
Nor is the night unwih'd; while vital heat,
Light, life, and joy, the dubious day forake.
Meantime, in able cincture, hadows vat,
Deep-ting'd, and damp, and congregated clouds,
And all the vapoury turbulence of heaven
Involve the face of things. Thus Winter falls,
A heavy gloom oppreive o'er the world.
Thro' Nature hedding influence malign
And rou • es up the eeds of dark dieae.
The oul of man dies in him, loathing life
And black with more than melancholy views,
The cattle <> and o'er the •• rrowed land

Freh from th • plough, the un dico •
<> fl • cks,
Untended preading, crop the wholeome <>
Along the woods, along the moorih ens,
Sighs the ad Genius of the coming torm;
And up amongt the looe disjointed cliffs,
And fractur'd mountains wild, the brawling brook
And cave, preageful, end a hollow • oan,
Reounding long in l ••• ening Fancy's ear.
Then comes the father of the tempet forth,
Wrapt in black glooms. Firt joyles, rains obcure
Dah on the mountain's brow, and hake the wood,
That grumbling wave below. Th' unightly plain
Lyes a brown de • uge; as the low-bent clouds
P • ur flood on flood, yet unexhauted till
Combine, and, deepening into night, hut up
The day's fair face. The wanderers <> you,
Each to his home re • ire; • a • e <…> love
To take their patime in the troubled air,
Or kimming •• utter round the dimply pool.
The cattle from th' untated fields return,
And ak, with meaning lowe, their wonted talls,
Or ruminate in the contiguous hade,
Thither the houehold feathery people croud,
The creted cock, with all his female train.
Penive, and dripping; while the cottage-hind
Hangs o'er th' enlivening blaze, and taleful there
Recounts his imple frolic; much he talks,
And much he laughs, nor recks the torm that blows
Without, and rattles on his humble roof.
Wide o'er • he brim, with many a torrent well'd.
And the mix'd ruin of its banks o'erpread,
At lat the rous'd-up river pours along
Reitles, roaring, dreadful, down it comes,
From the • de mountain, and the moy wild,
Th • o'er the anded valley floating preads,
• alm, luggih, ilent; till again contrain'd
Between two meeting hills, it burts away,
Where rocks and woods o'er hang the turbid tream;
There gathering triple force, rapid, and deep,
It boils, and wheels, and foams and thunders through.
Nature! great parent! whoe unceaing hand
Rolls round the eaons of the changeful year,
How mighty, how majetic, are thy works!
With what a pleaing dread they well the oul!
That ees aton • h'd! and atonih'd ings!
Ye too, ye winds! that now begin to blow,
With boiterous weep, I raie my vo • ce to you.
Where are your tores, ye powerful beings! ay,
Where your aërial magaz • nes reerv'd,
To well the brooding terrors of the torm!
In what far-ditant reg • on of the ky,
Huh'd in deep ilence, leep ye when 'tis calm?
When from the pallid ky the un decends,
With many a pot, that o'er his glaring orb
Uncertain wanders, ta • n'd; red fiery treaks
Begin to fluh around. The reeling clouds
Stagger with dizzy poie, as doubting yet
Which mater to obey: while riing low,
Blank, in the leaden-colour'd eat, the moon
Wears a wan circle round her blunted horns.
Seen thro' the turb'd, fluctuating air,
The tars obtue emit a hiver'd ray;
Or frequent eem to hoot athwart the gloom,
And long behind them trail the whitening blaze.
Snatch'd in hort eddies, plays the wither'd leaf;
And on the flood the dancing feather floats.
With broadened notrils to the ky up-turn'd,
The concious heifer nuffs the tormy gale,
Even as the matron, at her nightly tak,
With penive labour draws the iaxen thread,
The wated taper and the crackling flame
Foretel the blat. But chief the plumy race,
The tenants of the ky, its changes peak.
Retiring from the downs, where all day long
They pick'd their canty fair, a blackening train,
Of clamorous rooks thick urge their weary flight,
And eek the cloing helter of the grove;
Aiduous, in his bower, the wailing owl
Plies his ad ong. The cormorant on high
Wheels from the deep, and creams along the land
Loud hrieks the oaring hern; and with wild wing
The circling ea-fowl cleave the flaky clouds.
Ocean, unequal pres'd, with broken tide
And blind commotion heaves; while from the hore,
Eat into caverns by the retles wave,
And foret-rutling mountain, comes a voice,
That olemn-ounding bids the world prepare.
Then iues forth the torm with udden burt,
And hurls the whole precipitated air
Down, in a torrent. On the paive main
Decends th' ethereal force, and with trong gut
Turns from its bottom the dicoloured deep.
Thro' the black night that its immene arounds,
Lah'd into foam, the fierce-conflicting brine
Seems o'er a thouand raging waves to burn:
Meantime the mountain billows, to the clouds
In dreadful tumult well'd urge above urge,
Burt into chaos with tremendous roar,
And anchor'd navies from their tations drive,
Wild as the winds acros the howling wate
Of mighty waters: now th' inflated wave
Straining they cale, and now impetuous hoot
Into the ecret chambers of the deep.
The wint'ry Baltic thund'ring o'er their head.
Emerging thence again, before the breath
Of full-exerted heaven they wing their coure,
And dart on ditant coats; if ome harp rock,
Or hoal inidious break not their career,
And in looe fragments fling them floating round.
Nor les at land the looened tempet reigns.
The mountain thunders; and its turdy ons
Stoop to the bottom of the rocks they hade.
Lone on the midnight teep, and all aghat,
The dark wayfaring tranger breathles toils,
And, often falling, climbs againt the blat.
Low waves the rooted foret, vex'd, and heds
D • h'd down, and catter'd, by the tearing winds
••• duous fury, its gigantic limbs.
Thus truggling thro' the diipated grove,
The whirling tempet raves along the plain;
And on the cottage thatch'd, or lordly roof,
Keen-fatening, hakes them to the olid bae.
Sleep frighted flies; and round the rocking dome,
For entrance eager, howls the avage bla • .
Then too, they ay, thro' all the burthen'd ai • ,
Long groans are heard, hrill ounds and ditant ighs,
That, utter'd by the Demon of the night,
Warn the devoted wretch of woe and death.
Huge uproar lords it wide. The clouds commix'd
With tars wift-gliding weep along the ky.
All Nature reels. Till Nature's KING, who oft
Amid tempetuous darknes dwells alone,
And on the wings of the careering wind
Walks dreadfully erene, commands a calm;
Then traight air, ea, and earth are huh'd at once.
As yet, 'tis midnight deep. The weary clouds,
Slow-meeting, mingle into olid gloom.
Now, while the drowy world lies lot in leep,
Let me aociate with the erious Night,
And Contemplation her edate compeer;
Let me hake off th'intruive cares of day,
And lay the meddling enes all aide.
Where now, ye lying vanities of life!
Ye ever-tempting, ever-cheating train!
Where are ye now! and what is your amount?
Vexation, diappointment, and remore.
Sad, ickening thought! and yet deluded Man,
A cene of crude disjointed viions pat,
And broken lumbers, ries till reolv'd,
With new-fluh'd hopes, to run the giddy round.
Father of light and life! thou GOOD SUPREME!
O teach me what is good! teach me THYSELF!
Save me from folly, vanity, and vice,
From every low puruit! and feed my oul
With knowledge, concious peace, and virtue pure;
Sacred, ubtantial, never-fading blis!
The keener tempets rie: and uming du •
From all the livid eat, or piercing north,
Thick clouds acend in whoe capacious womb
A vapoury deluge lies, to now congeal'd.
Heavy they roll their fleecy world along;
And the ky faddens with the gathered torm.
Thro' the huh'd air the whitening hower decends,
At firt thin wavering; till at lat the flakes
Fall broad, and wide, and fat, dimming the day,
With a continual flow. The cherih'd fields
Put on their winter-robe of puret white.
'Tis brightnes all; ave where the new now melts
Along the mazy current. Lo, the woods
Bow their hoar head; and, ere the languid un,
Faint from the wet, emits his evening ray
Earth's univeral face, deep hid and chill,
Is one wide dazzling wate, that burys wide
The works of Man. Drooping, the labourer-ox
Stands cover'd o'er with now, and then demands
The fruit of all his toil. The fowls of heaven,
Tam'd by the cruel eaon, croud around
The winnowing tore, and claim the little boon
Which PROVIDENCE aigns them. One alone,
The red-breat, acred to the houhold gods,
Wiely regardful of th' embroiling ky,
In joyles fields, and thorny thickets, leaves
His hivering mates, and pays to truted Man
His annual viit. Half afraid, he firt
Againt the window beats; then, brik, alights
On the warm hearth: then hopp • ng o'er the floor
Eyes all the miling family akance,
And pecks, and tarts, and wonders where he is:
Till more fam • liar grown, the table crumbs
Attract his lender feet. The foodles wilds
Pour forth their brown inhabitants. The hare,
Tho' timorous of heart, and hard beet
By death in various forms, dark nares, and dogs,
And more unpitying Men, the garden eeks,
Urg'd on by fearles want. The bleating kind
Eye the black heaven, and next the glit • ning earth,
With looks of dumb depair; then, ad dipers'd,
Dig for the wither'd herb thro heaps of now.
Now, hepherds, to your helples charge be kind,
Baffle the raging year, and fill their penns
With food at will; lodge them below the torm,
And watch them trict: for from their bellowing eat,
In this d • re eaon, oft the whirlwinds wing
Sweeps up • he burthen of whole wintry plains
At one wide waft, and o'er the haples flocks,
H • d in the hollow of two neighbouring hills,
The billowy tempet whelms; till upward urg'd,
The valley to a hining mountain wells.
Tipt with a wreath high curling in the ky.
As thus the nows arie; and foul, and fierce,
All Winter drives along the darkened air;
In his own looe revolving fields, the wain
Diater'd tands; ees other hills acend,
Of unknown joyles brow; and other cenes,
Of horrid propect, hag the trackles plain;
Nor finds the river, nor the foret, hid
Beneath the formles wild; but wanders on
From hill to dale, till more and more atray.
Impatient flouncing thro' the drifted heaps,
Stung wi • h the thoughts of home; the thoughts of home
Ruh on his nerves, and call their vigour forth
In many a vain attempt. How inks his oul!
What black depair, what horror fills his heart?
When for the duky pot, which fancy feign'd
His tufted cottage riing thro' the now,
He meets the roughnes of the middle wate,
Far from the tract, and blet abode of Man;
While round him night reitles cloes fat,
And every tempet howling o'er his head,
Renders the avage wildernes more wild.
Then throng the buy hapes into his mind,
Of cover'd pits, unfathomably deep,
A dire decent! beyond the power of frot,
Of faithles bogs; of precipices huge,
Smooth'd up with now; and, what is land, unknown
What water, of the till unfrozen pring,
In the looe marh or olitary lake,
Where the freh fountain from the bottom boils.
Thee check his fearful teps and down he ink •
Beneath the helter of the hapeles drift,
Thinking o'er all the bitternes of death,
Mix'd with the tender anguih Nature hoots
Thro' the wrung boom of the dying Man,
His wife, his children, and his friends uneen.
In vain for him th' officious wife prepares
The fire fair-blazing and the vetment warm;
In vain his little children, peeping out
Into the mingling torm, demand their fire,
With tears of artles innocence. Alas!
Nor wife, nor children, more hall he behold,
Nor friends, nor acred home. On ev • ry nerve
The deadly Winter eizes: huts up ene;
And, o'er his inmot vi • als creeping cold,
Lays him along the nows, a tiffened core,
Stretch'd out, and bleaching in the northern blat.
Ah little think the gay licentious proud,
Whom pleaure, power, and affluence urround;
They, who their thoughtles hours in giddy mirth,
And wanton, often cruel, riot wate:
Ah little think they, while they dance along,
How many feel, this very moment, death,
And all the ad variety of pain.
How many ink in the devouring flood,
Or more devouring flame. How many bleed,
By hameful variance betwixt Man and Man.
How many pine in want, and dungeon-glooms;
Shut from the common air, and common ue
Of their own limbs. How many drink the cup
Of baleful grief, or eat the bitter bread
Of miery. Sore pierc'd by wintry winds,
How many hrink into the ordid hut
Of cheerles poverty. How many wake
With all the fiercer tortures of the mind,
Unbounded paion, madnes, guilt, remore;
Whence tumbled headlong from the height of life,
They furnih matter for the tragic Mue.
Even in the vale where widom loves to dwell,
With friendhip, peace, and contemplation join'd,
How many, rack'd with honet paions, droop
In deep retir'd-ditres. How many tand
Around the death-bed of their dearet friends,
And point the parting anguih. Thought fond Man
Of thee, and all the thouand nameles ills,
That one inceant truggle render life,
One cene of toil, of uffering, and of fate,
Vice in his high career would tand appall'd,
And heedles rambling Impule learn to think;
The concious heart of Charity would warm,
And her wide wih Benevolence dilate;
The ocial tear would rie, the ocial igh;
And into clear perfection, gradual blis,
Refining till, the ocial paions work.
And here can I forget the generous The jail-committee, in the year 1729. band,
Who, touch'd with human woe, redreive earch'd
Into the horrors of the gloomy jail?
Unpitied and unheard, where miery moans;
Where icknes pines; where thirt and hunger burn,
And poor misfortune feels the lah of vice.
While in the land of liberty, the land
Whoe every treet and public meeting glow
With open freedom, little tyrants rag'd;
Snatch'd the lean morel from the tarving mouth;
Tore from cold wintry limbs the tatter'd weed;
Even robb'd them of the lat of comforts, leep;
The free-born BRITON to the dungeon chain'd,
Or, as the lut of cruelty prevail'd,
At pleaure mark'd him with inglorious tripes;
And cruh'd out lives, by ecret barbarous ways,
That for their country would have toil • d or bled.
O great deign! if executed well,
With patient care, and widom-temper'd zeal.
Drag forth the leg • l monters into light,
Wrench from their hands Oppreion's iron rod,
And bid the cruel feel the pains they give.
Much till untouch'd remains; in thi • rank age,
Much is the patriot's weeding hand requir'd.
The toils of law (what dark inidious Men
Have cumbrous added to perplex the truth,
And lengthen imple juti • e into trade)
How glorious were the day that aw thee broke,
And every man within the reach of right
By wintry famine rous'd from all the tract
Of horrid mountains which the hining Alps,
And wavy Apennine, and Pyrennees,
Branch out tupendous into ditant lands;
Cruel as death, and hungry as the grave!
Burning for blood! bony, and gaunt, and grim!
Aembling wolves in raging troops decend;
And, pouring o'er the country, bear along,
Keen as the north wind weeps the gloy now.
All • s their prize. They faten on their teed,
Pres him to death and pierce his mighty heart.
Nor can the bull his awful front defend,
Or hake the murdering avages away.
Rapacious, at the mother's throat they fly,
And tear the creaming infant from her breat.
The god-like face of Man avails him nought.
Even beauty, force divine! at whoe bright glance
The generous lion tands in oftened gaze,
Here bleeds, a haples, unditinguih'd prey,
But if, appris'd of the evere attack,
The country be hut up, lur'd by the cent
On churchyards drear (inhuman to relate!)
The diappointed prowlers fall, and dig,
The hrouded body from the grave; o'er which,
Mix'd with foul hades, and frighted ghots, they howl.
Among thoe hilly regions, where embrac'd
In peaceful vales the happy Grions dwell!
Oft, ruhing udden from the loaded cliffs,
Mountains of now their gathering torrents roll.
From teep to teep loud thundering down they come,
A wintry wate in dire commotion all;
And herds, and flocks, and travellers and wains,
And ometimes whole brigades of marching troops,
Or hamlets leeping in the dead of night,
Are deep beneath the mothering ruin whelm'd.
Now, all amid the rigours of the year,
In the wild depth of Winter, while without
The ceaeles winds blow ice, be my retreat,
Between the groaning foret and the hore
Beat by the boundles multitude of waves,
A rural, helter'd, olitary cene;
Where ruddy fire and beaming tapers join,
To chear the gloom. There tudious let me it,
And hold high convere with the MIGHTY DEAD;
Sages of antient time as gods rever'd,
As gods beneficent, who bles'd mankind
With arts, and arms, and humaniz'd a world.
Rous'd at th'inpiring thought, I throw aide

That wah'd th' ungenial pole, will ret no more
Beneath the hackles of the mighty north;
But, rouing all their waves, reitles heave.
And hark! the lengthening roar continuous runs
Athwart the rifted deep: at once it burts,
And piles a thouand mountains to the clouds.
Ill fares the bark with trembling wretches charg'd,
That, tos'd amid the floating fragments, moors
Beneath the helter of an icy ile,
While night o'erwhelms the ea, and horror looks
More horrible. Can human force endure
Th' aembled michiefs that beiege them round?
Heart-gnawing hunger, fainting wearines,
The roar of winds and waves, the cruh of ice,
Now ceaing, now renew'd with louder rage.
And in dire echoes bellowing round the main.
More to embroil the deep, Leviathan
And his unwieldy train, in dreadful port,
Tempet the looen'd brine, while thro' the gloom,
Far from the bleak inhopitable hore,
Loading the winds, is heard the hungry howl
Of famih'd monters, there awaiting wrecks.
Yet PROVIDENCE, that ever-waking Eye,
Looks down with pity on the feeble toil
Of mortals lot to hope, and lights them afe,
Thro' all this dreary labyrinth of ate.
'Tis done! dread WINTER preads his latet glooms
And reigns tremendous o'er the conquer'd year,
How dead the vegetable kingdoms lyes!
How dumb the tuneful! Horror wide extends
His deolate domain. Behold, fond Man!
See here thy pictur'd life; pas ome few years,
Thy flowering Spring, thy Summer's ardent trength,
Thy ober Autumn fading into age,
And pale concluding Winter comes at lat,
And huts the cene. Ah! whither now are fled
Thoe dreams of greatnes? thoe unolid hopes
Of happines? thoe longings after fame?
Thoe retles cares? thoe buy butling days?
Thoe gay pent fetive nights? thoe veering thoughts
Lot between good and ill, that har'd thy life?
All now are vanih'd! VIRTUE ole urvives,
Immortal, never-failing friend of Man,
His guide to happines on high. And ee!
'Tis come, the glorious morn! the econd birth
Of heaven, and earth! awakening Nature hears
The new-creating word, and tarts to life,
In every heightened form, from pain and death
For ever free. The great eternal cheme,
Involving all, and in a perfect whole
Uniting as the propect wider preads,
To reaon's eye refin'd clears up apace.
Ye vainly wie! ye blind preumptuous! now,
Confounded in the dut, adore that POWER,
And WISDOM oft arraign'd: ee now the caue,
Why unauming worth in ecret liv'd,
And dy'd, neglected: why the good man's hare
In life was gall and bitternes of oul:
Why the lone widow and her orphans pin'd
In tarving olitude; while Luxury,
In palaces, lay training her low thought,
To form unreal wants: why heaven-born Truth,
And Moderation fair, wore the red marks
Of upertition's courge: why licens'd Pain,
That cruel poiler, that emboom'd foe,
Imbittered all our blis. Ye good ditres'd!
Ye noble few! who here unbending tand
Beneath life's preure, yet bear up a while,
And what your bounded view, which only aw
A little part, deem'd Evil, is no more:
The torms of WINTRY TIME will quickly pas,
And one unbounded SPRING incircle all.

div.head: A HYMN.
div.l: THee, as they change, ALMIGHTY FATHER, thee
Are but the varied GOD. The rolling year
Is full of thee. Forth in the pleaing Spring
THY beauty walks, THY tendernes and love.
Echo the mountains round; the foret miles;
And every ene, and every heart is joy.
Then comes THY glory in the ummer-months,
With light and heat refulgent. Then THY un
Shoots full perfection thro' the welling year:
And oft THY voice in dreadful thunder peaks;
And oft at dawn, deep noon, or falling eve,
By brooks and groves, in hollow-whipering gales.
THY bounty hines in Autumn unconfin'd,
And preads a common feat for all that lives.
In Winter awful THOU? with clouds and torms
Around THEE thrown, tempet o'er tempet roll'd,
Majetic darknes! on the whirlwind's wing,
Riding ublime, THOU b • d't the world adore,
And humblet Nature with thy northern Blat.
MYSTER • OUS round! what kill, what orce divine,
Deep felt, in thee appear! a imple train,
Yet o delightful mix'd, with uch kind art,
Such beauty and beneficence combin'd;
Shade, unperceiv'd, o oftening into hade;
And all o forming an harmonious whole;
That as they till ucceed, they ravih till.
But •• nd'ring oft, with brute unconcious Gaze,
Ma •• marks not THEE, marks not the mighty Hand
That, ever-buy, wheels the ilent Spheres;
Works in the ecret Deeps; hoots, teaming, thence
The fair Profuion that o'erpreads the Spring:
Flings from the Sun direct the flaming Day;
Feeds every Creature; hurls the Tempet forth;
And, as on Earth this grateful Change revolves.
With Tranport touches all the Springs of Life.
NATURE, attend! join every living Soul,
Beneath the pacious Temple of the Sky,
In Adoration join; and, ardent, raie
One general Song! To HIM, ye vocal Gales,
• reathe oft, whoe SPIRIT in your Frehnes breathes:
Oh talk of HIM in olitary Glooms!
Where, o'er the Rock, the carcely-waving Pine
Fills the brown Shade with a religious Awe.
And ye, Whoe bolder Note is heard afar,
Who hakes th' atonih'd World, lift high to Heaven
Th' impetuous Song, and ay from whom you rage.
HIS Praie, ye Brooks, attune, ye trembling Rills;
And let me catch it as I mue along.
Ye headlong Torrents, rapid, and profound;
Ye ofter Floods, that lead the humid Maze
Along the Vale; and thou, majetic Train,
A ecret World of Wonders in thyelf,
Sound HIS tupendous Praie; whoe greater Voice
Or bids you roar, or bids your Roarings fall.
Soft-roll your In • ene, Herbs, and Fruits, and Flowers,
In mingled clouds to HIM; whoe Sun exalts,
Whoe Breath perfumes you, and whoe Pencil paints.
Ye Forets bend, ye Harvets wave, to HIM;
Breathe your till Song into the Reaper's Heart,
As home he goes beneath the joyous moon.
Ye that keep watch in heaven, as earth aleep
Unconcious lyes, effue your mildet beams,
Ye contellations, while your angels trike,
Amid the pangled ky, the ilver lyre.
Great ource of day! bet image here below
Of thy Creator, ever pouring wide,
From world to world, the vital ocean round,
On Nature write with every beam HIS praie.
The thunder rolls: be huh'd the protrate world;
While cloud to cloud returns the olemn hymn.
Bleat out afreh, ye hills: ye moy rocks,
Retain the ound: the broad reponive • owe,
Ye valleys raie; for the GREAT SHEPHERD reigns
And his unuffering kingdom yet will come.
Ye woodlands all, awake: a boundles ong
Burt from the groves! and when the retles day,
Expiring, lays the warbling world aleep,
Sweetet of birds! weet Philomela, charm
The lit'ning hades, and teach the night HIS praie.
Ye chief, for whom the whole creation miles,
At once the head, the heart, and tongue of all,
Crown the great hymn! in warming cities vat,
Aembled men, to the deep organ join
The long reounding voice, oft breaking clear,
At olemn paues, through the welling bae;
And as each mingling flame encreaes each,
In one united ardor rie to heaven.
Or if you rather chue the rural hade,
And find a fane in every acred grove;
There let the hepherd's flute, the virgin's lay,
The prompting eraph, and the poet's lyre,
Still ing the GOD OF SEASONS, as they roll.
For me, when I forget the darling theme,
Whether the bloom blows, the ummer-ray
Ruets the plain, inpiring Autumn gleams;
Or Winter rie in the blakening eat;
Be my tongue mute, may fancy paint no more,
And, dead to joy, forget my heart to beat!
Should fate command me to the farthet verge
Of the green earth, to ditant barbarous climes,
Rivers unknown to Song; where firt the un
Gilds Indian mountains, or his etting beam
Flames on th' Atlantic iles: 'tis nought to me:
Since GOD is ever preent, ever felt,
In the void wate as in the city full;
And where HE vital breathes, there mut be joy.
When even at lat the olemn hour hall come,
And wing my mytic flight to future worlds,
I chearful will obey: there, with new powers,
Will riing wonders ing: I cannot go
Where UNIVERSAL Love not miles around,
Sutaining all yon orbs and all their ons;
From eeming evil till educing good
And better thence again, and better till,
In infinite progreion. But I loe
Myelf in HIM, in LIGHT INEFFABLE!
Come then, expreive ilence, mue HIS praie.

div.head: BRITANNIA. A POEM.

q.l: — Et tantas audetis t • llere moles?
Quos ego—ed m • tos praetat componere fluctus.
Pot mihi non imili poena commia laetis.
Maturate fugam, regique ha • c dicite vetro:
Non illi imperium pelagi, aevumque trid • ntem,

div.l: AS on the ea-beat Shore Britannia et
Of her degenerate Sons the faded Fame,
Deep in her anxious Heart, revolving ad:
Bare was her throbbing Boom to the Gale,
That hoare, and hollow, from the bleak Surge blew;
Looe flow'd her Trees; rent her azure Robe;
Hung o'er the Deep, from her majetic Brow
She tore the Laurel, and he tore the • ay.
Nor ceas'd the copious Grief to bathe her Cheek;
Nor ceas'd her Sobs to murmur to the Main.
Peace dicontented nigh, departing, tretch'd
Her Dove-like Wings. And War, tho' greatly rous'd,
Yet mourn'd his fetter'd hands. While thus the Queen
Of Nations poke; and what he aid the Mue
Recorded, faithful, in unbidden Vere.
EVEN not yon Sail, that, from the ky-mixt Wave,
Dawns on the Sight, and wafts the ROYAL YOUTH Frederic Prince of Wales, then lately arrived..
A Freight of future Glory to my hore;
Even not the flattering View of golden Days,
And riing Periods yet of bright Renown,
Beneath the Parents, and their endles Line
Thro' late revolting Time, can ooth my Rage;
While, unchatis'd, the inulting Spaniard dares
Infet the trading Flood, full of vain War,
Depie my Navies, and my Merchants eize;
As, truting to fale Peace, they fearles roam
The World of Waters wild, made, by the Toil,
And liberal Blood of glorious Ages, mine:
Nor burts my leeping Thunder on their Head.
Whence this unwonted Patience? this weak Doubt?
This tame beeeching of rejected Peace?
This meek Forbearance? this unnative Fear,
To generous Britons never known before?
And ail'd my Fleets for this; on Indian Tides
To float, unactive, with the veering Winds?
The Mockery of War! while hot Dieae,
And Sloth ditemper'd, wept off burning Crouds,
For Action ardent; and amid the Deep,
Inglorious, unk them in a watry Grave.
There now they lie beneath the rolling Flood,
Far from their Friends, and Country unaveng'd?
And back the drooping War-hip comes again,
Dipirited, and thin; her Sons aham'd
Thus idly to review their native Shore;
With not one Glory parkling in their Eye,
One Triumph in their Tongue. A Paenger,
The violated Merchant comes along;
That far-ought Wealth, for which the noxious Gale
He drew, and weat beneath Equator Suns,
By lawles Force detain'd; a Force that oon
Would melt away, and ev'ry Spoil reign,
Were once the Britih Lion heard to roar.
Whence is it that the proud Iberian thus,
In their own well-aerted Element,
Dares rouze to Wrath the Maters of the Main?
Who told him, that the big incumbent War
Would not, ere this, have roll'd his trembling Ports
In moky Ruin? and his guilty Stores,
Won by the Ravage of a butcher'd World,
Yet unaton'd, unk in the wallowing Deep,
Or led the glittering Prize into the Thames?
THERE was a time (Oh let my languid Sons
Reume their Spirit at the rouzing Thought!)
When all the Pride of Spain, in one dread Fleet,
Swell'd o'er the lab'ring Surge; like a whole Heaven
Of Clouds, wide-roll'd before the boundles Breeze
Gaily the plendid Armament along
Exultant plough'd, reflecting a red Gleam,
As unk the Sun, o'er all the flaming Vat;
Tall, gorgeous, and elate; drunk with the Dream
Of eay Conquet; while their bloated War,
Stretch'd out from Sky to Sky, the gather'd Force
Of Ages held in its capacious Womb.
But oon, regardles of the cumbrous Pomp,
My dauntles Britons came, a gloomy few,
With Tempet black, the goodly Scene deform'd,
And laid their Glory wate. The Bolts of Fate
Reitles thunder'd thro' their yielding Sides;
Fierce o'er their Beauty blaz'd the lurid Flame;
And eiz'd in horrid Grap, or hatter'd wide,
Amid the mighty Waters, deep they unk.
Then too from ev'ry Promontory chill,
Rank Fen, and Cavern where the wild Wave works,
I wept confederate Winds, and well'd a Storm.
Round the glad Ile, natch'd by the vengeful Blat,
The catter'd Remnants drove; on the blind Shelve,
And pointed Rock, that marks th' indented Shore,
Relentles dah'd, where loud the Northern Main
Howls thro' the fractur'd Caledonian Iles.
But ince bow vat it grew, how abolute,
Even in thoe troubled Times, when dreadful Blake
Aw'd angry Nations with the Britih Name,
Let every humbled State, let Europe ay,
Sutain'd, and ballanc'd, by my naval Arm.
Ah what mut thee im • ortal Spirits think
Of your poor Shifts? Thoe, for their Country's good,
Who fac'd the blacket Danger, knew no Fear,
No mean Submiion, but commanded Peace.
Ah how with Indignation mut they burn?
(If aught, but Joy, can touch etherial Breats)
With Shame? with Grief? to ee their feeble Sons
Shrink from that Empire o'er the conquer'd Seas,
For which their Widom plan'd, their Councils glow'd,
And their Veins bled thro' many a toiling Age.
OH firt of human Bleings! and upreme!
Fair Peace! how lovely, how delightful Thou!
By whoe wide Tie, the kindred Sons of Men,
Like Brothers live, in Amity combin'd.
And unupicious Faith; while honet Toil
Gives every Joy, and to thoe Joys a Right,
Which idle, barbarous Rapine but uurps.
Pure is thy Reign; when, unaccurs'd by Blood,
Nought, ave the Sweetnes of indulgent Showers,
Intead of mangled Carcaes, ad-cene,
When the blythe heaves lie catter'd o'er the Field;
When only hining Shares, the crooked Knife,
And Hooks imprint the vegetable Wound;
When the Land bluhes with the Roe alone,
The falling Fruitage and the bleeding Vine.
Oh, Peace! thou ource and oul of ocial Life;
Beneath whoe calm, inpiring Influence,
Science his Views enlarges, Art refines,
And welling Commerce opens all her Ports;
Blet be the Man divine who gives us Thee!
Who bids his Trumpet huh his horrid Clang,
Nor blow the giddy Nations into Rage;
Who heaths the murderous Blade; the deadly Gun
Into the well-pil'd Armory returns;
And, every Vigour from the Work of Death,
To grateful Indutry converting, makes
The Country flourih, and the City mile.
Unviolated, him the Virgin ings;
And him the miling Mother to her Train.
Of him the Shepherd, in the peaceful Dale,
Chaunts; and, the Treaures of his Labour ure,
The Hubandman of him, as at the Plough,
Or Team, he toils. With him the Sailor ooths,
Beneath the trembling Moon, the Midnight Wave;
And the full City, warm from Street to Street,
And Shop to Shop, reponive, rings of him.
Nor joys one Land alone; his Praie extends
Far as the Sun rolls his diffuive Day;
Far as the Breeze can bear the Gifts of Peace,
Till all the happy Nations catch the Song.
WHAT would not Peace! the Patriot bear for thee
What painful Patience? What inceant Care?
What mixt Anxiety? What leeples Toil?
Even from the Rah protected what Reproach?
For he thy Value knows; thy Friendhip he
To human Nature: but the better thou,
The richer of Delight, ometimes the more
Inevitable War; when Ruffian Force
Awakes the Fury of an injur'd State.
Even the good patient Man, whom Reaon rules;
Rouz'd by bold Inult, and injurious Rage,
With harp, and udden Check, th' atonih'd Sons
Of Violence confounds; firm as his Caue,
His bolder Heart; in awful Jutice clad;
His Eyes effulging a peculiar Fire;
And, as he charges thro' the protrate War,
His keen Arm teaches faithles Men no more
To dare the acred Vengeance of the Jut.
AND what, my thoughtles Sons, hould fire you more,
Than when your well-earn'd Empire of the Deep
The leat beginning Injury receives?
What better Caue can call your Lightning forth?
Your thunder wake? Your dearet Life demand?
What better Caue, than when your Country ees
The ly Detruction at her Vitals aim'd?
For oh, it much imports you, 'tis your all,
To keep your Trade entire, entire the Force,
And honour of your Fleets; o'er that to watch
Even with a Hand evere, and jealous Eye.
In Intercoure be gentle, generous, jut,
By Widom polih'd, and of Manners fair;
But on the Sea be terrible; untam'd,
Unconquerable till: let none ecape,
Who hall but aim to touch your Glory there.
Is there the Man, into the Lion's Den
Who da • es intrude, to natch his young away?
And is a Briton eiz'd? and eiz'd beneath
The lumbering Terrors of a Britih Fleet?
Then ardent rie! oh great in Vengeance rie;
O'erturn the Proud, teach Rapine to retore:
And as you ride ublimely round the World,
Make every Veel toop, make every State
At once their Welfare and their Duty know.
This • s your Glory; this your Widom; this
The native Power for which you were deign'd
By Fate, when Fate deign'd the firmet State
That e'er was eated on the ubject Sea;
A State, alone, where Liberty hould live,
In thee late Times, this Evening of Mankind,
When A • hens, Rome and Carthage are no more,
The World almot in lavih loth diolv'd.
For this thee Rocks around your Coat were thrown;
For this your Oaks, peculiar harden'd, hoot
Strong into turdy Growth; for this your Hearts
Swell with a ullen Courage, growing till
As Danger grows; and Strength, and Toil for this
Are liberal pour'd o'er all the fervent Land.
Then cherih this, this unexpenive Power,
Undangerous to the Public, ever prompt,
By lavih Nature thrut into your Hand;
And, unencumber'd with the Bulk immene
Of Conquet, whence huge Empires roe, and ell
Self-cruh'd. Extend your Reign from hore to hore.
Where-e'er the Wind your high Behets can blow,
And fix it deep on this eternal Bae.
For hould the liding Fabric once give Way,
Soon lacken'd quite and pat Recovery broke,
It gathers Ruin as it it rolls along
Steep-ruhing down to that devouring Gulph,
Where many a mighty Empire bury'd lyes.
And hould the big redundant Flood of Trade,
In which ten thouand thouand Labours join
Their everal Currents, till the boundles Tide
Rolls in a radiant Deluge o'er the Land;
Should this bright Stream, the leat inflected, point
Its Coure another Way, o'er other Lands
The various Treaures would reitles pour,
Ne'er to be won again; its ancient Tract
Left a vile Channel, deolate and dead,
With all around a mierable Wate.
Not Egypt, were her better Heaven, the Nile
Turn'd in the Pr • de of flow; when o'er his Rocks,
And roaring Cataracts, beyond the Reach
Of dizzy Viion pil'd, in one wide Flah
An Ethiopian Deluge foams again;
(Whence wondering Fable trac'd him from the Sky)
Even not that Prime of Earth where Harvets croud
On untill'd Harvets, all the teeming Year,
If of the fat o'erflowing Culture robb'd,
Were then a more uncomfortable Wild,
Steril, and void; than of her Trade depriv'd,
Britons, your boated Ile: her Princes unk;
Her high-built Honour moulder'd to the Dut;
Unnerv'd her Force; her Spirit vanih'd quite;
Her unfrequented Ports alone the Sign
Of what he was; her Merchants catter'd wide;
Her hollow hops hut up; and in her treets,
Her Fields, Woods, Markets, Villages and Roads,
The chearful Voice of Labour heard no more.
OH let not then wate Luxury impair
That manly Soul of Toil which trings your Nerves,
And your own proper Happines creates!
Oh let not the oft penetrating Plague
Creep on the free-born Mind! and working there,
With the harp Tooth of many a new-form'd Want,
Endles, and idle all, eat out the Heart
Of Liberty; the high Conception blat;
The noble Sentiment, th' impatient Scorn
Of bae Subject • on, and the welling Wih
For general Good, eraing from the Mind:
While nought ave narrow Selfihnes ucceeds,
And low Deign, the neaking Paions all
Let looe, and reigning in the rankled Breat.
Induc'd at lat by carce-perceiv'd Degrees,
Sapping the very Frame of Government,
Sloth, Ignorance, Dejection, Flattery, Fear,
Oppreion raging o'er the Wate he makes;
The human Being almot quite extinct;
And the whole State in broad Corruption inks,
Oh hun that Gulph, that gaping Ruin hun!
And countles Ages roll it far away
From you, ye heaven-belov'd! May Liberty!
The Light of Life! the Sun of human kind!
Whence Heroes, Bards, and Patriots borrow Flame,
Even where the keen depreive North decend •
Still pread, exalt, and actuate your Powers!
While lavih outhern Climates beam in vain.
And may a public Spirit from the Throne,
Where every Virtue its, go copious forth
Live o'er the Land! the finer Arts inpire;
Make thoughtful Science raie his penive Head,
Blow the freh Bay, bid Indutry rejoice,
And the rough Sons of lowet Labour mile.
As when pro • u • e of Spring, the looen'd Wet
Lifts up the pining Year and balmy breathes
You • h, Life and Love, and Beauty o'er the World.
BUT hate we from thee melancholy Shores,
Nor to deaf Winds, and Waves, our fruitles Plaint
Pour weak; the Country claims our active Aid!
That let us roam; and where we find a park
Of public Virtue, blow it into Flame.
Lo! now my Sons, the Sons of Freedom! meet
In awful Senate; thither let us fly;
Burn in the Patriot's thought, flow from his Tongue
In fearles Truth; myelf transform'd preide,
And hed the Spirit of Britannia round.
THIS aid; her fleeting Form and airy Train,
Sunk in the Gale; and nought but ragged Rocks
Ruh'd on the broken Eye, and nought was heard
But the rough Cadence of the dahing Wave.

div.head: ODE for MUSIC ON ST. CECILIA's DAY.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: DESCEND, ye Nine! decend and ing;
The breathing intruments inpire,
Wake into voice each ilent tring,
And weep the ounding lyre!
In a adly-pleaing train
Let the warbling lute complain:
Let the loud trumpet ound
'Till the roofs all around
The hrill echoes rebound:
While in more lengthen'd notes and low,
The deep, majetic, olemn organs blow.
Hark! the numbers oft and clear
Gently teal upon the ear;
Now louder, and yet louder rie,
And fill with preading ounds the kies;
Exulting in triumph now well the bold notes,
In broken air, trembling, the wild muic floats;
'Till, by degrees, remote and mall,
The tr •• n • decay,
And melt away,
In a dying, dying fall.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: By Muic, minds an equal temper know,
Nor well too high, nor ink too low.
If in the breat tumultuous joys arie,
Muic her oft auaive voice applies;
Or, when the oul is pres'd with cares,
Exalts her in enlivening airs.
Warriors he fires with animated ounds;
Pours b • lm into the bleeding lover's wounds:
Melancholy lifts her head,
Morpheus rouzes from his bed,
Sloth unfolds his arms and wakes,
Lit'ning Envy drops her nakes;
Intetine war no more our Paions wage,
And giddy Factions hear away their rage.

lg.head: III
lg.l: But when our Country's caue provokes to Arms,
How mar • ial muic ev'ry boom warms!
So when the firt bold veel dar'd the eas,
High on the tern the Thracian rais'd his train,
Wh •• e Argo aw her kindred trees
De • c •• d from Pelion to the main.
Tranported demi-gods too • round,
And men grew heroes at the ound,
Enflam'd with glory's charms:
Each chief his ev'nfold hield diplay'd,
And half unheath'd the hining blade:
And eas, and rocks, and kies rebound
To arms, to arms, to arms!

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: But when thro' all th' infernal bounds,
Which flaming Phlegeton urrounds,
Love, trong as Death, the Poet led
To the pale nations of the dead,
What ounds were heard,
What cenes appear'd,
O'er all the dreary coats!
Dreadful gleams,
Dimal creams,
Fires that glow,
Shrieks of woe,
Sullen moans
Hollow groans,
And cries of tortur'd ghots!
But hark! he trikes the golden lyre;
And ee! the tortur'd ghots repire,
See, hady forms advance!
Thy tone, O Siyphus, tands till,
Ixion rets upon his wheel,
And the pale pectres dance!
The Furies ink upon their iron beds,
And nakes uncurl'd hang lit'ning round their heads.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: By the treams that ever flow,
By the fragran' winds that blow
By thoe happy ouls who dwell
In yellow me • d of Aphodel,
Or Amaranthine bowers;
By the hero's armed hades,
Glitt'ring thro' the gloomy glades;
By the youths that dy'd for love,
Wand'ring in the myrtle grove,
Retore, retore Euridice to life:
Oh take the huband, or return the wife!
He ung, and hell conented
To hear the Poet's prayer;
Stern Proerpine relented,
And gave him back the fair.
Thus ong could prevail
O'er death, and o'er Hell,
A conquet how hard and how glorious?
Tho' fate had fat bound her,
With Styx nine times round her,
Yet muic and love were victorious.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: But oon, too oon, the lover turns his eyes:
Again he falls, again he dies, he dies!
How wilt thou now the fatal iters move!
No crime was thine, if 'tis no crime to love.
Now under hanging mountains,
Beide the falls of fountains
Or where the Hebrus wanders,
Rolling in meanders,
All alone,
Unheard, unknown,
He makes his moan:
And calls her ghot,
For ever, ever lot!
Now with Furies urrounded,
Depairing, confounded,
He trembles, he glows,
Amidt Rhodopoe's nows:
See, wild as the winds o'er the deert he flies;
Hark! Haemus reounds with the Bacchanal's cries—
Ah ee! he dies!
Yet ev'n in death Euridice he ung,
Euridice till trembled on his tongue,
Euridice the woods,
Euridice the floods.
Euridice the rocks, and hollow mountains rung.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Muic the fiercet grief can charm,
And ate's everet rage diarm:
Muic can often pain to eae,
And make depair and madnes pleae:
Our joys below it can improve,
And antedate the blis above.
This the divine Cecilia ound
And to her Maker's praie confin'd the ound,
When the full organ joins the tuneful quire,
Th'immortal pow'rs incline their ear;
Borne on the welling notes our ou • s apire,
While olemn a • s improve the acred fire,
And angels lean from heav'n to hear.
Of Orpheus n • w no more let Poets tell,
His numbers rais'd a hade from hell,
Her's lift the oul to heav'n.

div.head: ALEXANDER's FEAST. OR, THE POWER of MUSICK, An ODE. In Honour of St. Cecilia's Day.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: 'TWAS at the Royal Feat, for Peria won,
By Philip's Warlike Son:
Aloft in awful State,
The God-like Hero ate
On his imperial Throne:
His valiant Peers were plac'd around;
Their Brows with Roes and with Myrtles bound.
(So hould Deert in Arms be crown'd:)
The lovely Thais by his Side,
Sate like a blooming Eatern Bride
In Flow'r of Youth and Beauty's Pride.
Happy, happy, happy Pair!
None but the Brave,
None but the Brave,
None but the Brave deerves the Fair.

l.hi: None but the Brave deerves the Fair.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Timotheus plac'd on high,
Amid the tuneful Quire,
With flying Fingers touch'd the Lyre:
The trembling Notes acend the Sky,
And Heav'nly Joys inpire.
The Song began from Jove;
Who left his blisful Seats above,
(Such is the Pow'r of mighty Love.)
A Dragon's fiery Form bely'd the God:
Sublime on radiant Spires He rode,
When He to fair Olympia pres'd:
And while He ought her nowy Breat,
Then, round her lender Wait he curl'd,
And t • mp'd an Image of himelf, a Sov'reign of the World.
The lit'ning Crowd admi • e the lofty Sound.
A preent Deity, they hout around:
A preent Deity the vaulted Roofs rebound:
With ravih'd Ears
The Monarch hears,
Aumes the God,
Affects to nod,
And eems to hake the Spheres.

l.hi: And eems to hake the Spheres.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: The Pr • i • of Ba ••• us then • he weet Mu • cian ung;
The jolly God in Triumph comes;
Sound the Trumpets; beat the Drums;
Fluh'd with a purple Grace
He hews his honet Face,
Now gives the Hautboys breath; He comes, He comes,
Bacchus, ever Fair and Young,
Drinking Joys did firt ordain:
Bacchus' Bleings are a Treaure,
Drinking is the Soldier's Pleaure:
Rich the Treaure,
Sweet the Pleaure;
Sweet is Pleaure after Pain.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Bacchus' Bleings are a Treaure;

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Sooth'd with the Sound the King grew vain;
Fought all his Battles o'er again;
And thrice he routed all his Foes; and thrice he lew the lain.
The mater aw the Madnes rie,
His glowing Cheeks, his ardent Eyes;
And while he Heav'n and E • r • h defy'd,
Chang'd his Hand, and cheek'd his Pride.
He choe a mournful Mue.
Soft Pity to infue:
He ung Darius Great and Good,
By too evere a Fate,
Fallen, fallen, fallen, fallen,
Fallen from his high Etate,
And weltring in his Blood:
Deerted at his utmot Need,
By thoe his former Bounty fed:
On the bare Earth expos'd he lies,
With not a friend to cloe his Eyes.
With down-cat Looks the joyles Victor ate,
Revolving in his alter'd Soul
The various Turns of Chance below;
And, now, and then, a igh he tole;
And Tears began to flow.

l.hi: The various Turns of Chance below;
And, now and then, a igh he tole;

lg.head: V.
lg.l: The mighty Mater mil'd, to ee
That Love was in the next Degree:
'Twas but a Kindred-Sound to move;
For Pity melts the Mind to Love.
Softly weet, in Lydian Meaures,
Soon he ooth'd his Soul to Pleaures.
War, he ung, is Toil and Trouble;
Honour but an empty Bubble.
Never ending, till beginning,
Fighting till, and till detroying,
If the World be worth thy Winning,
Think, O think, it worth Enjoying.
Lovely Thais its beide thee,
Take the Good the Gods provide thee.
The Many rend the Skies, with loud Applaue;
So Love was crown'd, but Muic won the Caue.
The Prince, unable to conceal his Pain,
Gaz'd on the Fair
Who caus'd his Care,
And igh'd and look'd, and igh'd again:
At length, with Love and Wine at once oppres'd,
The vanquih'd Victor unk upon her Breat.

l.hi: The Prince, unable to conceal his Pain,
And igh'd and look'd and igh'd again:
At length, with Love and Wine at once oppres'd,
The vanquih'd Victor unk upon her Breat.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Now trike the Golden Lyre again:
A louder yet, and yet a louder Strain.
Break his Bands of Sleep aunder,
And rouze him, like a ra • tling Peal of Thunder.
Hark, hark, the horrid Sound
Has • ais'd up his Head,
As awak'd from the Dead,
And amaz • d, he tar • s around.
Revenge, Revenge, Timotheus cries,
See the Furies arie:
See the Snakes that they rear,
How they his in their Hair,
And the Sparkle • that fl • h • rom their Eyes!
Behold a ghatly Band,
Each a Torch in his Hand!
Thoe are Grecian Ghots, that in Battle were lain,
And unbury'd remain
Inglorious on the Plain.
Give the Vengeance due
To the Valiant Crew.
Behold how they tos their Torches on high,
How they point to the Perian Abodes,
And glitt'ring Temples of their Hotile Gods,
The Princes applaud, with a furious Joy;
And the King eiz'd a Flambeau, with Zeal to detroy;
Thais led the Way,
To light him to his Prey,
And like another Helen, fir'd another Troy.

lg.head: CHORUS.

l.hi: And the King eiz'd a Flambeau, with Zeal to detroy;

lg.l: Thais led the way,

l.hi: To light him to his Prey,

lg.l: And like another Helen, fir'd another Troy.

lg.head: VII
lg.l: Thus, long ago,
Ere heaving Bellows learn'd to blow,
While Organs yet were mute;
Timotheus, to his breathing Flute,
And ounding Lyre
Cou'd well the Soul to Rage, or kindle oft Deire
At lat divine Ceci • ia came,
The weet Enthuiat, from her acred Store,
Enlarg'd the f • me • narrow Bounds,
• nd added Length to olemn Sounds,
Wi • h Nature's Mother- • it, and Arts unknown before.
Let old Timotheus yield the Prize,
Or both divide the Crown;
He rais'd a Mortal to the kies;
She drew an Angel down.

lg.head: Grand CHORUS.
lg.l: At lat, Divine Cecilia came,

l.hi: The weet Enthuiat, from her acred Store,
And added Length to olemn Sounds,
With Nature's Mother-Wit, and Arts unknown before.

lg.l: Let old Timotheus yield the Prize,

l.hi: He rais'd a Mortal to the Skies;

lg.l: HAPPY the man, whoe wih and care
A few paternal acres bound,
Content to breathe his native air,
In his own ground.
Whoe herds with milk, whoe fields with bread,
Whoe flocks upply him with attire,
Whoe trees in ummer yield him hade,
In winter fire.
Blet, who can unconcern'dly find
Hours, days, and years lide oft away,
In health of body, peace of mind,
Quiet by day,
Sound leep by night; tudy and eae,
Together mixt; weet recreation:
And innocence, which mot does pleae
With meditation.
Thus let me live, uneen, unknown,
Thus unlamented let me die,
Steal from the world, and not a tone,
Tell where I lie.

div.head: The dying Chritian to his Soul. ODE.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: VITAL park of heav'nly flame:
Quit, oh quit this mortal frame:
Trembling, hoping, ling'ring, flying,
Oh the pain, the blis of dying!
Ceae, fond Nature, ceae thy trife,
And let me languih into life.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Hark! they whiper; Angels ay,
Siter Spirit, come away.
What is this aborbs me quite?
Steals my enes, huts my ight,
Drowns my pirits, draws my breath?
Tell me, my oul, can this be Death?

lg.head: III.
lg.l: The world recedes; it diappears!
Heav'n opens on my eyes! my ears
With ounds eraphic ring:
Lend, lend your wings! I mount, I fly!
O Grave? where is thy V • ctory?
O Death! where is thy Sting?

div.head: THE UNIVERSAL PRAYER. DEO OPT. MAX.

lg.l: FATHER of All! in ev'ry Age,
In ev'ry Clime ador'd,
By Saint, by Savage, and by Sage,
Jehovah, Jove, or Lord!
Thou Great Firt Caue, leat undertood,
Who all my Sene confin'd
To know but this, that Thou art Good,
And that myelf am blind;
Yet gave me, in this dark Etate,
To ee the Good from Ill;
And binding Nature fat in Fate,
Left free the Human Will.
What Concience dictates to be done,
Or warns me not to do,
This, teach me more than Hell to hun,
That, more than Hea • 'n purue.
What Bleings thy free Bounty gives,
Let me not cat away;
For God is paid when Man receives,
T' enjoy is to obey.
Yet not to Earth's contracted Span
Thy Goodnes let me bound,
Or think Thee Lord alone of Man,
When thouand Worlds are round:
Let not this weak, unknowing Hand
Preume thy Bolts to throw.
And deal Damnation rou • d the Land,
On each I judge thy Foe.
If I am right, thy Grace impart,
Still in the right to tay:
If I am wrong, oh teach my Heart
To find that better Way.
Save me alike from foolih Pride,
Or impious Dicontent,
At ought thy Widom has deny'd,
Or aught thy Goodnes lent.
Teach me to feel another's Woe,
To hide the Fault I ee;
That Mercy I to others hew,
That Mercy hew to me.
Mean tho' I am, not wholly o,
Since quicken'd by thy Breath;
O lead me whereo • 'er I go,
Thro' this Day's Life or Death.
This Day, be Bread and Peace my Lot:
All ele beneath the Sun,
Thou know't if bet betow'd or not,
And let thy Will be done.
To thee, whoe Temple is all Space,
Wh • e Altar, Earth, Sea, Skies!
One Chorus let all Being raie!
All Nature's Incene rie!

div.head: ELEGY To the MEMORY of an UNFORTUNATE LADYSee the Duke of Buckingham's veres to a Lady deigning to retire into a Monatery compared with Mr. P • pe's Le • ters to everal Ladies, p. 206. quarto edition She eems to be the ame peron whoe unfortunate death is the ubject of this poem..
div.l: WHAT beck'ning ghot, along the moon-light hade
Invites my teps, and points to yonder glade!
'Tis he!—but why that bleed • ng boom gor'd,
Why dimly gleams the viionary word?
Oh ever beauteous, ever friendly! • ell,
Is it, in Heav'n a crime to love too well?
T • bear too tender, or too firm a heart,
To act a Lover's or a Roman's part?
Is there no bright reverion in the ky,
For thoe who greatly think, or bravely die?
Why bade ye ele, ye pow'rs! her oul apire
Above the vulgar flight of low deire?
Ambition firt prung from your blet abodes;
The glorious Fault of Angels and of Gods
Thence to their images on earth it flows,
And in the breats of Kings and Heroes glows.

Mot ouls, 'tis true, but peep out onc •
• n age,
Dull ullen pris'ners in the body's cage:
Dim lights of life, that burn a length of years,
Ueles, uneen, as lamps in epulchres;
Like Eatern Kings, a lazy tate they keep,
And cloe conf • n'd to their own palace leep.
From thee perhaps (ere nature bade her die)
Fate natcht her early to the pitying ky,
As into air the purer pirits flow,
And ep'rate from their kindred dregs below;
So flew the oul to its congenial place,
Nor left one virtue to redeem her race.
But thou fale guardian of a charge too good,
Thou mean deerter of a Brother's blood!
See on thee ruby lips the trembling breath,
Thee cheeks now fading at the blat of death;
Cold is the breat that warm'd the world <>
And thoe love darting eyes mut roll no mor •
Thus, if eternal jutice rules the ball,
Thus hall your wives, and thus your children fal •
On all the line a udden vengeance waits,
And frequent h • re h • l • bei • g • your gates.
There paengers hall tand and pointing ay,
(While the long funeral blackens all the way,)
Lo! thee were they, whoe ouls the Furies teel'd,
And curs'd with hearts unknowing how to yield.
Thus unlamented pas the crowd away,
The gaze of fools, and pageant of a day!
So perih all, whoe breats ne'er learn'd to glow
For others good, or melt at others woe.
What can atone (oh ever injur'd hade!)
Thy fate unpity'd, and thy rites unpaid?
No friend's complaint, no kind dometic tear
Pleas'd thy pale ghot, or grac'd thy mournful bier:
By foreign hands thy dying eyes were clos'd,
By foreign hands thy decent limbs compos'd,
By foreign hands thy humble grave adorn'd,
By trangers honour'd, and by trangers mourn'd!
What tho' no friends in able weeds appear,
Grieve for an hour, perhaps, then mourn a year,
And bear about the mockery of woe
To midnight dances, and the public how?
What tho no weeping loves thy ahes grace,
Nor polih'd marble emulate thy face?
What tho' no acred earth allow thee room,
Nor hallow'd dirge be mutter'd round thy tomb?
Yet hall thy grave with riing flow • rs be dret,
And the green • urf l • e lightly on thy breat:
There hall the mor • her earliet tears betow,
There the firt roes of the year hall blow;
While A • ge • s with their ilver w • ngs o'erhade
The ground now acred by thy reliques made.
So peaceful rets without a tone, a name,
What once had beauty, titles, wealth and fame.
How lov'd, how honour'd once, avails thee not,
To whom related, or by whom be got;
A heap of dut alone remains of thee,
'Tis all thou art and all the proud hall be!
Poets themelves mut fall like th • e they ung,
Deaf the prais'd ear, and mu • e the tuneful tongue.
Ev'n he, whoe oul now me •• s in mournful lays,
Shall hortly want the gen'rous tear he pays;
Then from his cloing eyes thy form hall part,
And the lat pang hall • ear thee f • om his heart.
Life's idle buines at one gap be o'er,
The Mue forgot, and thou belov'd no more!

div.head: VENI CREATOR SPIRITUS. Tranlated in Paraphrae.
div.l: CReated Spirit, by whoe Aid
The World's Foundations firt were laid,
Come pour thy Joys on Human Kind;
From Sin and Sorrow et us free;
And make thy Temples worthy Thee.
O, Source of uncreated Light,
The Father's promis'd Paraclete! Comforter.
Thrice Holy Fount, thrice Holy Fire,
Our Hearts with Heav'nly love inpire;
Come, and thy Sacred Unction bring
To anctify us, while we ing!
Plenteous of Grace, decend from high,
Rich in thy ev'nfold Energy!
Thou Strength of his Almighty Hand,
Whoe Pow'r does Heaven and Earth command.
Proceeding Spirit, our Defence,
Who do't the Gift of Tongues dipene,
And crown't thy Gift with Eloquence!
Refine and purge our Earthly Parts;
But, Oh, inflame and fire our Hearts!
Our Frailties help, our Vice controul;
Submit the Senes to the Soul;
And when rebellious they are grown,
Then, lay thy Hand, and hold 'em down.
And Peace, the Fruit of Love, betow:
And, let our Feet hould tep atray;
Protect, and guide us in the way.
Make us Eternal Truths receive,
And practie all that we believe:
Give us thyelf, that we may ee
The Father, and the Son, by thee.
Immortal Honour, endles Fame,
Attend th' Almighty Father's Name;
The Saviour Son be glorify'd,
Who for lot Man's Redemption dy'd,
And equal Adoration be,
Eternal Paraclete, to thee.
